    2014-01-23: I hate it when my phone dies, for whatever reason! I am on call a lot so my phone must work. This is a really nice power source. It is easy to use, has helped me out many times when my phone is dead and I need to make or receive a call, and fits in my purse or pocket nicely. It has a male plug projection so the cover must be kept on when not used, to protect it. The only minor problem is it is hard on nails to open it, but the lid must stay on to protect the plug so I accept that. It works for about 3 charges when new, but I just use it when my battery runs low and I am on call. I recommend, would buy another, and I hope this helps someone.

    Rating: 5

    2013-06-19: I have a Samsung galaxy S2, so use the enclosed micro USB to USB cable in order to both charge the battery and charge my phone. While some reviewers mention a problem with the battery pack not seating properly, this is only a problem with iPhones, because the cord running from the battery to the phone works just fine.Overall, I like the small form factor, the fact that it is black, and that it came with the cord I needed. It charged my Kindle all the way, and it charges my phone to 100%. The only complaint I have is that it doesn't automatically shut off when it's finished charging, so even if I only needed a portion of the charge, the entirety of the battery pack still becomes depleted because I don't remember to go back in an hour and shut it off. That said, for the price this is an excellent little product and it certainly saved my bacon on a recent trip where I didn't have access to a charging station for 24 hours.

    Rating: 4

    2013-04-04: yes there are a lot of battery juice packs out there, but I've never seen one quite like this. Aside from the fact that the design is fashionably sleek and compact for carrying around, the price is extremely cheap for what it has to offer; what I like about it the most is that this PowerBot TNT 2600 unit already has a built in lightning adapter which made my life a lot easier without having the need of bringing an extra cable around all the time. Furthermore, this PowerBot TNT power bank charges more than just iphone 5 or idevices, it can also be used to charge microUSB devices such as hTC or Samsung smartphones as well, which makes it very very handy for the friends and families around me who are on android phones (great gift for heavy duty mobile device users). This juice pack does not have a led flash light however, but I am quite fine without it as I can use my phone as a flash light anytime as long as it's got power. Overall, it's a classy little powerhouse that keeps the power thirsty mobile devices properly fed.

    2013-03-23: Note: The price is Fifteen dollars now - NOT Seventy-nine.There are lots of chargers out there that are very good, like,RAVPower 10400mAh Dynamo-On-the-Go RP-PB07 External Battery Pack Charger. Powered by Samsung Battery Cells. Limited Edition Model (originally labeled 10000mah). Includes Free Wall Charger and Bonus Bag. 5V 3A Dual USB Output. Fit for Android & Apple De...andPowerGen PGMPP8400 8400mAh External Battery Pack High Capacity Power Bank Charger Dual USB output for Apple iPhone 5 4s 4 3Gs 3G, iPod Touch, iPad mini 1 2 3 4, The New iPad 3/ HTC sensation, XE, XL, One X S V, Thunderbolt, Inspire 4G , EVO 3D, EVO 4G, .... These are all about the size of a pack of cigarettes and fairly lightweight. I didn't think you could improve in any other way. What I like about the POWER BANK is that it can charge ALL my devices, like my iPhone 5, my iPod and best of all, my iPad mini. In fact, if you check out the specifications, you'll see it can charge many different kinds of devices that the others cannot. It's very small and very portable. Using an included Lightening connector and standard USB port (a short 4-inches), it charges in about 2-3 hours. It also holds it charge for many days. The usage of the charge depends on what you use it for. It can charge my iPad mini in less than an hour as well as my iPhone. There is a mini port input on one end and a standard USB input on the other.The best part about this device is the price and the small size. It will not give you the charge of the other two items I mentioned as it simply does not have the same size lithium battery, but it makes an excellent backup.(Compatible with: iPhone, iPad, Samsung Galaxy, LG, Motorola HTC, Nokia, Android, Smartphone, MP3, MP4 Video Player, GPS, Tablets, Cell Phones, iPhone5 iPod, Nano7 iPod Touch5, New iPad 4 and iPad Mini). Product generously supplied by manufacturer for an honest review.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-11: Any charger with a lightning plug built in should have 2 things going for it:1 - it must charge lightning devices, which means 10watts so it can do the iPhone 5, iPad and iPad Mini.2 - it must be recognized by those devicesUnfortunately, while this charger seems to do job 1 most of the time (which is good), it fails utterly at 2. No iDevice I have (iP 5, iPad Mini) will connect without the dreaded "This accessory may not be compatible..." notice. I'm fine with that for devices not specifically built for lightning connectors, but if you have a device that - essentially - only works with iDevices, then it should be made to work with iDevices. Certification is expensive, but critical. I'd rather pay more than have a product that might not work.I should point out here that on several occasions - specifically with both WiFi and bluetooth enabled - the phone was not being charged while the device was attached. So sometimes it even fails at job 1.Second issue: The internal parts are not well fixed in place. If you shake the device - gently - you can hear things moving around. I have two units, both exhibit this problem. This is a rechargeable battery that gets put into backpacks, bags, jackets - the thing will get a little jostled from time to time just by nature of being a portable battery. It *must* be solidly built or it will break and could cause damage to anything near it.I cannot recommend this item. Though the concept is brilliant, and there are very few devices like this available, the execution and workmanship are far below acceptable.

  • B00F2SGBXK

    $B00F2SGBXK

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2014-01-08: I chose this phone for the .01 price tag, added it to my att account, but now that I have it? So worth it. I'm nearly ALWAYS on my phone, and after 10 hours, I'm still dealing with more than half of the battery charge. The interface is smooth, clean, easily adjusted, and very fun. This is a solidly constructed phone, and very easily used. People should know this phone's value. No, it's not a samsung, a moto, or an HTC. I have had them all. I have this now...and it's worth it.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-29: So a little background on me. I typically switch phones monthly, amongst all the high end smart phones. I like to try different ones, and have had every high end Samsung phone, GS2, GS3, GS4, Note 2, etc. and also the HTC one, LG Optimus G pro, Nexus 4 etc. also, all my house TVs are Samsung smart Tv's and I often like to project my phone videos and pics onto the 55" TV in the den. (much like Samsung phones)I use a galaxy note 8.0 tablet for car and home etc.I typically switch phones b/c I don't believe there was one phone that had exactly what I want...although each had "some" good stuff to add.Now, I believe that a phone is a computer..with phone abilities. I'm not alone in this. I'm NOT the guy who says all phones nowadays work fine, and there is no need for improvement or speed increases. I run 2 companies, have a child, and have a hobby competing in dance events on weekends. I often use my camera for video, pics, and watch videos on my phone. I am not a gamer kid. I rely on my phone to be fast, effective, and the software should make it easy for me to operate a business and be dependable with the ability to jot things down quickly, send emails and share stuff often. And I should be able to communicate...AND NOT RUN OUT OF BATTERY too soon.So, here goes my take on the G2. (I'm on Tmobile)I have used the G2 for about 4 weeks now. I try out almost every feature and see if it's useful for my purposes. I consider it a better phone than the Galaxy S4, and by preference better than the HTC One. I do consider the HTC one to be an amazing phone of all my choices. Great job HTC.Screen:The screen size is huge relative to the size of the phone itself. I think all phones should be this way. I felt like we should be carrying almost all screen without the extra bulk...and the G2 finally provided that. The extra border is useless to me, and just makes for a bigger device in my pocket and hand, with unusable area. The screen is beautiful. Daylight viewing is much better than all other phones accept the HTC One. I can see this thing clearly in very bright outdoor situations, I can't say that about Samsung GS4. The screen is a pleasurable experience. 5.2 inches doesn't bother me. I'm average size. I could have been just as happy with 5" with no border. Either works. I will say that the Official quick window case makes me like the phone 10x more. The case is super thin, but adds function and protection. The china knockoff cases are too thick for me.I feel that 5" and 5.2" are acceptable screen sizes. I was happy with the HTC One (4.7") but watching videos were just too small for my taste.BRIGHT WHITES: I prefer this. And LG hits it right. I enjoy that part of apple devices actually. Clean and bright. LG has that for me.Build Quality:I give it a 10/10 for a plastic phone. Super sturdy and feels solid in the hand. No creeks and cracks like the cheap Galaxy S4. Samsung gave plastic phones a bad name. LG makes it's plastic phones with quality feel. Now, I do not care for the plastic material in terms of being a little slippery. I use the quickwindow case, but wish they would have used a Nexus material for the back cover. Not a deal breaker, but a wish. Not a huge issue for me.Speakers:Not so good. Do the job, but not the best. This is the one area they could have made better, but I assume they ran out of money and had to pick which options mean the most to consumers. Me, I always use Bluetooth (LG HBS730) and don't use the speakers much. I used the HTC one speakers, on occasion, and found they were nice, but not worth the extra " in height to the phone. My preference. I wouldn't want them the extra height.Phone quality:Phone works great. Bluetooth works great. No issues with hearing people with our without Bluetooth. Speaker calls are acceptable when needed.Quick Charging:This phone charges ridiculously fast. They don't tout this feature near enough. I can be at 15%, and plug it in for 20 minutes, and be at 40% with the LG 2A charger (or any 2 amp charger including my car charger). WOW. Now THAT IS a USEFUL feature! A 3,000mAh battery plus quick charging. Much better than HTC and Samsung I used.Battery life:Best of any phone I have used. With a full 1080p screen, and never using "battery saver" this phone has a great battery life. A full 4+ hours better than the GS4, and ridiculously longer than the HTC One. I sync 4 email accounts every 15 minutes and listen to music throughout the day.Lag:No lag. Very quick. Much like the HTC One (which I consider the HTC phone to be very nice in that area)Buttons on the back of the phone:LG placed the buttons (volume and Power) on the back of the phone. They said its more natural than the standard way with buttons on the side: My take? BRILLIANT. It's very nice to not have ANY buttons on the side of the phone, and my grip on the fold is much better holding it the way they recommend. It won't slip out of my hand AT ALL. Very good feature. I hope they keep it with all their future phones. I use the Knock on feature mostly, so I rarely use the back buttons but this was a good move IMHO. If Samsung or Apple would have done this, people would consider it brilliant. It is a good habit and functional.Knock on feature:Great feature. No need for a power button. Works great for me. One secret is when the phone is on, and in an app etc, just tap at the top area twice near the notification bar, to turn it off. (sometimes in an app a double tap activates the app stuff). This alleviates that in that situation.A worthy feature worth keeping. I find myself trying to do that with my Samsung galaxy note 8.0 tablet.LED Light:Love it, works great. Glad they included it for notifications when phone is off. I use it often.Camera:I won't go into a lot of detail here, but I think it's the best camera I have used. Optical image stabilization is a great feature, and the rest of the features are similar to Samsung in terms of modes. I'll let the camera review blogs cover this. I like it and consider it premium. Pics and video are truly amazing on this screen.USB OTG:I like the ability to plug a flash drive into the phone and have access to it to move files or watch movies or whatever. Every phone should have these drivers in their software. And most high end androids do. Apple doesn't. Cables are $3 on Amazon. Use it for business and transferring files quickly.Software:I have used phone software extensively from everyone accept Sony. HTC, Samsung and Nexus etc.Here is my take on using the software for business and pleasure. I like it. Thoroughly.Here is why.Quickmemo: works great. For both screen saves etc. I actually use it a lot. I never really used the Samsung "memo" feature. I prefer Quickmemo being in the notification bar with wifi, Bluetooth etc. I turn it on when I am on the phone and need to jot something down. It quickly saves to my notebook and I'm happy (similar to galaxy note 2,3 notebook without the pen). HTC doesn't have this option for business, and Samsung is lacking (maybe not the note 3 I don't know)VUtalk:Meh. I guess in the rare occasion I had someone with an LG phone I was chatting with, it may be useful. Can't say I use it. It's whatever.Browser:I like the browser viewing experience when on the web. I consider it nice like the HTC One...which I considered the best. Smooth transitions, quick, and not jagged or laggy. Almost up to par with Apple in smoothness. Now, I am a big fan of "whiter whites" and this is where I think the LG shines (along with the HTC One). My one problem with the Galaxy S4, was dingy whites. It bugs me...although I like Samsungs darker blacks. My eyeballs need a bright white like Apple's.Keyboard:On par with HTC One, much better than the GS4 in terms of accuracy (for me anyway). I don't need swiftkey or swype anymore and I get to keep the numbers above the keypad.Basically I like the software adds. The stuff I don't use, I turn off. i appreciate the fact that when I get a text, it shows up in its own little window over any screen I am on. Very non intruding, yet lets me answer texts right then. Works the same when you get phone calls. VERY NICE feature.I appreciate the option to add themes from the stock launcher. (see OG pro themes for freebies on XDA)I also appreciate that I can change the app draw icon size to large. Very nice feature other phones do not have.Lastly, I am amazed and saddened at how the price of this phone has dropped so soon. It's still an amazing phone and I consider the best (note 3 as well)...but without the marketing hype, people don't buy it as much. Which is silly to me.That's it for now, will update when I have time and think of other useful things.

    Rating: 5

    2014-01-17: Pros-1. Excellent performance. Incredibly fluid and pleasant experience.2. Very long battery life.3. Nice big display. Excellent for watching videos on the go.4. Camera is excellent. Almost as good as a regular point and shoot.5. 32 GB of internal storage.6. The buttons on the back are great once you get used to them.Cons-1. Can be difficult to operate with one hand.2. Software bugs.3. No MicroSD card slot or removable battery.4. Quick Remote can be much better.5. LG launcher could be better.6. It is a fragile fingerprint magnet if you don’t use a cover.Having used the LG G2 as my primary phone for the last 2 months and a half I think it is enough time to write a fairly competent review of my experience. My experience with the device has been very pleasant. I love the phone, but as with any other electronic device it has its pros and its cons. I will explain with more detail each of the above pros and cons below.Pros (continuation)1. Probably the single most important thing a smart phone needs to have is good performance. In this aspect this phone certainly delivers. It is fast, very fast. It will handle pretty much anything that you can throw at it. I currently have 1 live wallpaper running behind three home screens that have a total of 4 widgets. It still runs flawlessly. The transitions and animations are smooth and lag free. My previous phone was a Galaxy S3 and even though that phone was no slouch you can definitely tell the difference between the S3 and G2. I have seen the biggest improvement in the browser. The G2 is noticeably faster opening tabs and loading pages. It is also smoother when zooming in and out of web pages. As far as games are concerned I have not run many graphic intensive games. I do play a lot of Temple Run (my favorite game) and it runs with no problems.2. Battery life is often times the biggest weakness that a smart phone can have. That is not the case with the G2. Battery life is simply outstanding. I find it almost impossible to drain the battery with normal use in one day. For example, having use the phone for 14 hours today listening to podcasts and music, talking for about an hour, sending over 50 text messages and watching Netflix the battery is still at 60% before going to sleep. By the way, the screen brightness was at 75%. I absolutely hated having to always have to dim the screen in the S3 to have the battery last me a whole day. The only thing that takes a considerably amount of battery is the GPS. An hour using the GPS with full brightness will use about 25% of the battery. Not a big deal if you have a car charger though. Speaking of charging, this phone charges from 0-100% in two hours. Not bad at all for such a big battery.3. One of the most advertised aspects of this phone is its big beautiful display. There is no denying it is gorgeous. Absolutely great if you want to watch videos and pictures. Reading on the phone is comfortable. Colors are considerably toned down from the AMOLED displays on Samsung phones. The pixel count in the display is through the roof making texts incredibly sharp. I have not had any problems with burn in or flickering on the screen. Nothing more to say here, the screen is awesome.4. The camera of the phone is excellent by cell phone standards. There is no way it is going to replace a DSLR camera but it can replace a regular point and shoot. I have not used my regular point and shoot camera in the last two years. The LG G2 takes excellent pictures during the day and decent pictures at night. The pictures come out looking much better at night if you use the “night” mode on the camera app. But that can be a hassle when you are trying to take a picture quickly. LG has marketed OIS capabilities of the camera. Honestly, I see this having the biggest difference when I am taking videos. The videos definitely look less shaky than the ones in my S3. When it comes to taking pictures however I don’t think it really does much though. If I am not careful I still get the occasional blurry picture.5. The phone comes with 32 GB of memory. You can only use about 24 GB out of the box. After installing all my apps, music, taking a ton of picture and videos I still have 12 GB left. The storage is not a problem in my opinion. It is a good thing the base configuration of the phone comes with 32 GB and not 16 GB.6. I got used to the buttons being on the back of the phone after a few hours. It just becomes second nature after that. I actually find the position really comfortable now. I laugh whenever somebody tries to turn on my phone and they spend half a minute trying to figure out how to turn it on. If you are hesitating on this phone because of the back buttons DON'T. They are really no big deal. You might actually like it after a while. Even if you still don't like the buttons on the back you can always use the knock knock feature. That way you don't even have to use them if you don't want to.Cons (continuation)1. The bad thing that comes with having such a big phone is that it makes it pretty difficult to use with one hand. It can get annoying when you are driving and trying to change a song quickly on the phone. I have small hands for a guy but they are not exactly tiny either. The phone itself is pretty thin and it definitely packs the biggest screen possible with the space it has. The borders are very small. Just keep in mind it is still a huge phone, not much smaller than the Samsung Galaxy Note 2. That is great for watching movies but a real pain in the behind if you like using the phone with one hand.2. Having use the G2 the last few months you can definitely tell that the LG software team is not up to par with its hardware. I have experienced a few bugs while using the phone. None of them a huge deal but annoying nonetheless. For example, the knock knock feature should be more like knock knock knock knock. You definitely have to tap more than once to get it to work at times. Also when the knock knock feature is On and I am going to put the phone in my pocket or lay it on a table the phone turns On for no apparent reason. The problem goes away if I turn the knock feature off. But by far the most annoying bug I have had has been with the messenger application. I have had to completely turn the notifications for text messages off. The phone will not turn off the screen if I have the notifications On. It happens with every single text message application on the market which makes me think it is a bug in the operating system itself and how it is handling these notifications.3. This phone has no removable battery or micro SD slot. Not that big of a deal for me but I know many people care about it. It might be a problem in a couple of years if the battery starts giving me any problems and I need to replace it. By that time I figure I have gotten a new phone though.4. I have tried the quick remote feature a few times now. It works with all my TVs and DVDs on my house. The set up was simple enough. The problem is that it just doesn’t have nearly enough range and you have to point exactly straight at the device you are trying to operate. Often times it doesn’t receive the command and you have to press it again, again, and again. Very irritating. It is definitely a feature I see using in case of emergency only if I ever lose or break the other remote controls. It is a real shame though because I can see how useful it is to have all your remotes in one.5. When you first get the phone it comes with the LG stock launcher. It is not bad but it is not nearly as good as some other launchers you see on the Play Store. The Nova Prime launcher has less clutter while having more features and customizations. There are no swipe shortcuts in the LG launcher, which is one of the reasons I like Nova Prime so much. The LG launcher is very similar to the Samsung Touchwiz in a lot of ways. When you swipe down the notification panel it has toggles for rotation, wifi, data, Bluetooth, GPS, airplane mode, quick remote, NFC and more. It also has volume and a brightness slide bar so you can adjust them. All of these features in the notification area are very useful but it would be very nice if you could have the option to take them away. You can’t take them away which makes the notification feel cramped and cluttered.6. The final problem with the phone is that just like with a lot of phones a protective case is a must. The phone is fragile and it will definitely break if you drop it. Not only that, it is also fingerprint magnet. I had my phone two days before deciding it was a mistake to have it without a cover. The phone looks disgusting without a case. You can see the fingerprints from a mile away. The phone feels slippery without a case too. I ended up purchasing the Incipio Dual Pro case. It gives the phone a much better grip and minimizes fingerprints. It also offers very good protection while keeping the phone pretty slim. I highly recommend it.In conclusion, do I recommend this phone? I sure do. Overall, the phone is a fantastic devise. It is fast, has a nice screen and it takes good pictures and videos. The battery lasts all day which is a big plus in my opinion. Unfortunately I cannot it give 5 out of 5 because of all the cons I mentioned above. The biggest problem being the software bugs it has. To be fair though I don’t think there is a single phone in the market that is worth 5 out of 5 stars. There just isn’t. There is a lot of pretty impressive competition but you will always find fault with a product if you really want to look at it with an objective view. I really hope this review helped you decide whether this phone is right for you. If you are in the market for a new phone keep an open mind and go to the store to try different phones. There are other options besides Apple and Samsung phones and the LG G2 is certainly worthy competition.

    Rating: 4

    2013-10-12: I chose this phone after deciding to switch to AT&T from Sprint. It is an excellent overall phone with an awesome, bright, clear screen that is large but simultaneously does not make the phone seem huge. I love the "knock on" feature which allows me to turn on the phone without touching any buttons. Additionally it has a feature that detects when you are looking at the phone so that it will not go to sleep while you are reading, etc. It is very fast and I have no complaints so far. AT&T's service is leaps and bounds better than Sprint's in my area which also makes it much easier to enjoy this great phone.

    Rating: 5

    2014-01-18: Very good. Better than s4 by a mile. Must buy super phone. Faster more powerful than s4. Also awesome buttons on bottom.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-24: I've been using cell phones since the early 1990s, and smartphones for several years. Samsung, Apple, HTC and others certainly make excellent phones. I know. I've owned and used the iPhone 4s and iPhone 5, Samsung's S2, S3 and S4, and the HTC Amaze. This phone, however, the LG G2, is simply the best I've ever used. The screen is large with a gorgeous, brilliant display. The phone is very fast thanks to the Snapdragon quad-core processor. The battery is not removable, but it's a Li-Po 3000 mAh battery with the prodigious capacity to supply about 17 hours of talk time. I've been using the phone on and off all day and still have about 80% of the power left. There is no SD card slot. The phone's design is probably too slim and tight to accommodate a card, but it comes with 32 Gigs of internal memory, about 27 of which are available to the user. I've loaded literally thousands of songs, and about 60 video clips along with over 200 hundred photos and I still have seven gigs left. If I want more storage I can always use an external stick. I paid full price for the phone and it was still almost $200 less than the 32 gig iPhone, which also has a fixed battery and no SD card slot.The software LG stuffed into the phone is well thought-out. I hated the problems inherent in the iPhone's small virtual keyboards and the various links and points that had to be poked or drawn with great care to perform simple functions. I also hated the fact that when I spoke on the phone, my ear would inadvertently trigger the address book and sometimes cut off the conversation. No such problem on the G2. The keyboards are actually large enough to use and the helpful guessing at words as you type is very clever and very useful. There are so many things that LG has done with the software, and so many things I've yet to learn, that I can't comment further except to state that there's nothing I've seen in their pamphlets or propaganda that isn't the product of a profoundly wise and practical design team.Finally, there's the sound. None of the "professional" reviews of the LG G2 I've read or seen have delved into it, but the sound through ear buds is utterly superb. The HTC One comes close, but I think the LG G2 has the edge. One or two reviewers commented on the sound of the speakers. Well, the iPhone and Samsung speakers are just as mediocre, but anyone who listens to his or her cell phone speakers for the thrill of the experience is no audiophile. I listen through ear buds when I exercise and when I walk, and what I hear on the G2 is utterly astounding. At home I coupled the G2 with a cheap blue tooth speaker and was so impressed I bought the Bose SoundLink Mini. I listened to both the HTC One, with its excellent "Beats" audio and the G2, and to be frank preferred the G2, at least for classical music. I felt as if I were standing next the Steinway as the marvelous Yuja Wang played Rachmaninoff, or as if I were in the middle of the combo during a Jazz performance. Rock or pop may sound better on the HTC One, although I'm certain the G2 could also deliver anything the aficionados of Pop or Rock would want.I like the LG G2 very much and would recommend it to anyone. To me, it's simply the best value there is in cell phones today.

    Rating: 5

    Rating: 4

    2013-02-08: Note: I wrote this same review for the OtterBox Commuter Case, copied and pasted it here.I was comparing the Incipio 2-piece case with the OtterBox Commuter case, both of similar design. Frankly, the OtterBox fits the Samsung Galaxy S III more snugly, which is a good and bad thing. It is very difficult to take off. The Incipio slides on and off more easily, not to say it fits loosely, but I could see a possibility that in taking it out of a snug pocket, both of the pieces, which fit together, could come off. I always put it in a jacket pocket, which fits loosely, so I don't anticipate the problem. Whereas the OtterBox Commuter case hugs the entire phone tightly, I can bend the top and bottom of the silicone easily away from the phone, but it snaps back when I let go.Both cases use a polycarbonate exoskeleton over a silicone inner. Both silicone inners create a lip on the front, so if you do drop the phone on the front, the lip will protect it. The exoskeleton on the OtterBox is a slightly more rigid and thicker, so perhaps it might be a bit more protective. Furthermore, the OtterBox has tabs which fit over the headphone and charge ports, making it more protective against the elements.The killer to the OtterBox deal for me, though, is the button material that is used over the volume rocker. The volume rocker on the Galaxy, itself, is soft and quite easy to use -- almost too easily touch. The material that goes over the rocker on the OtterBox is terribly stiff. Both the salesperson in the Verizon store as well as me had to turn the phone on its side and really push down hard on the top or bottom of the OtterBox button in order to get the volume rocker switch to respond. Neither of us had good luck using a one-handed approach to the phone in that regard.Contrast that, not only to the Incipio, but to OtterBox's own Defender case, which has a button which is MUCH more pliable, making it far easier to manipulate the volume rocker underneath. If I needed a really a hearty, super-protective case (If my phone were to be in physically perilous situations a lot), I'd definitely consider the Defender. But the Defender case adds considerable bulk - both weight-wise and size-wise. If you think you bought an elegant phone with nicely curved lines, fogeddaboutit.Which brings me back to the Incipio. Perhaps it doesn't cross the 't's and dot the 'i's the way the Commuter case does, but it otherwise gives the normal user a substantial amount of protection -- quite adequate really. I have already dropped the phone twice in two weeks, including once on its face on my ceramic-tiled bathroom floor. No problem.

    Rating: 4

    2014-05-07: This case is just great, I'm a branch lover, and Incipio is one of them, all Incipio cases are great, this one is just fancy and elegant

    Rating: 1

    2011-12-27: I got this because I have an older BMW and the cigarette lighter (yes they used to be called that) was the kind that would pop up and push back down. I didn't want to have to keep pulling a big adaptor out each time. I leave the USB adaptor in the lighter and I just remove the plug. Also works great because my lighter socket is constant voltage (doesn't shut off with the key) I have left it in for over 1 week when I went on vacation and it doesn't draw enough residual voltage to drain the battery. My car started like normal when I got back. Excellent! I also use the other plug for the other accessories I use. Just works great!

    Rating: 5

    2011-04-09: Good morning ladies and gentlemen. I have a 2010 328i xDrive Sedan, with the 6FL package (aka, a USB port for music) and the logic7 stereo system upgrade. I'm an audiophile, so I decided that i wanted a high-quality digital media system in my car. I purchased a small, 2.5 inch external hard drive, and I tried to use it in my car. However, the USB port only provides 500mA, while the drive I had needed around 800-900. Therefore, I needed an external power solution.Meet the Griffin PowerJolt Dual Micro. When it says "Micro", it means "Micro". It fits 100% flush to the cigarette lighter socket. It has 2 usb ports, instead of the more traditional 1, so I can charge my phone and operate my music hard drive at the same time. My drive came with a USB Y-cable, so I plug the data end into the vehicle, and the power end into the PowerJolt, and it works like a charm.Only problem is (and this is certainly not the fault of the product, but more the way my vehicle is designed) that the cigarette lighter shuts off the moment you power down the car, but the USB port does not. Therefore, since it can't provide adequate power, the drive struggles to shut off, and it seems to cause the iDrive system to become confused, and then it locks out the USB port (probably a computer controlled safety system to prevent power drain on the battery), and it won't work until the iDrive computer does a 'cold' restart (takes about 10-15 minutes of the car being off, I haven't found out how to force a restart).In order to fix this problem, I'm looking for a small, USB battery pack that I can connect to the Griff PowerJolt, and then plug the Y-cable power into the USB battery pack. The drives goes into a lower power power save mode after about 10 minutes, so it just has to have enough gas to get it there, and then once the car's on again, the battery pack can recharge.But anyway, it's a great product, highly recommended. Just be aware that it only provides 1 amp per USB port, so it won't be able to charge an iPad. However, I suppose one could get a USB Y-cable with a USB female port on one end, and then one could plug in the 30-pin apple cable, and then the iPad would be getting 2 amps--not quite the 2.1 that the wall charger provides, but close enough so that you would be able to charge it.

    Rating: 5

    2011-08-31: I have been reticent to spend $29 on an Apple Car Charger for my iPhone 4 so I previously purchased two iPhone power cords off of eBay that are basically cheap knock offs. The first one worked for over a year and the second worked for 6 months before it broke apart. I realized it was time to get a quality item and was about to buy Apple brand when I saw this one from Kensington-which is a known brand for these types of things. Here are my thoughts:-Item works great. My last charger was VERY slow to charge my iPhone 4 and this one will charge it up in a flash. Beautiful stuff.-Removable cord-so if I need to use the cord to sync my iPhone 4 or another iPod-I can. I think that's pretty standard now-but some of the cheeps ones off of eBay do not have this option.-Dual charging capability. While I do not know how much slower it will charge the device-the fact that I could charge another USB item at the same time if needed is important and a great option to have for a passenger iPhone, Kindle, iPad, Navigation system, etc.-Very small profile so not big and bulky.-Cord for syncing is just the right length of not too short, but not too long.Potential negatives-Tough to see in the picture, but the device that goes in your cigarette lighter is VERY small and could be hard to get out. I was shocked when I saw how small it was. It may be that others have had problems with this and there certainly is not a lot of room to grasp this thing to take it out, but just enough for me.Overall, a great value at this price when the Apple version is twice as much with only 1 USB charger.

    Rating: 5

    2011-06-26: This thing rocks. Other chargers take up so much space; this thing takes up almost zero (outside of the socket). It also provides a full amp to each port, which is great. An absolutely wonderful product!

    Rating: 5

    2013-03-06: Bad internal design. Wire wound around a form touches the 12V lead from the socket, so when the thin varnish on the winding wears through... POOF. (See the picture I uploaded.) Visible smoke curls up and your device is fried. My Moto DroidX survived, apparently because Motorola knows how to buffer input power so a 12V surge from a 5V USB port won't do any damage, but Garmin doesn't do that.Not worth the risk. Use a manufacturer cord. It would be easy to anticipate and avoid this problem, but Griffin and the Ford Pinto are in the same category.

    Rating: 1

    2013-08-05: The wire works good. But the adapter split apart after 2 uses. The adapter is very small. Once I plugged it in, it was really hard to get it back out.

    Rating: 3

    2012-12-19: I haven't had any problems. It's nice to have 2 usb charging ports in one lighter adapter. I haven't had any problems with it.

    Rating: 4

    2012-03-22: I drive an 01 Audi A6. It's quite a popular model, yet I have trouble finding solutions to advancing technology that fit my vehicle AND wallet. This dual charger is exactly the type of simple and elegant upgrade I was hoping to make and luckily, Griffin and Amazon were there in the clutch as usual.The outlet in my A6 is hidden within a hide-away drawer at the bottom-center of my dash (below radio). Normally, car chargers are large and long. This not only fits perfectly within my hidden outlet, it also allows me to leave this dual charge in the outlet at all times - even when I need to close the drawer when the charger isn't in use. As others have mentioned, this may or may not sit flush with your outlet, but in my case (01 Audi A6) it fits perfectly, leaving just enough space for my pudgy fingers to pull the dual charger out with ease.Overall this is a fantastic charger and these days, it's a must.NOT TO MENTION THE BONUS CABLE!!!! I SAW A SIMILAR DUAL CHARGER FOR $3 MORE ON AMAZON THAT DIDN'T HAVE THIS CABLE. THIS IS THE WAY TO GO! YOU CAN NEVER HAVE TOO MANY IPHONE/IPOD/TABLET/CELL PHONE/ CABLES.

    Rating: 5

    2013-01-21: Extremely small like if it were any smaller you could not get it out of car outlet, fits flush with the end of the outlet and charges fast

    2014-07-15: This Universal Car Charger has gone through a lot of testing this month. We have used it on a camping trip, a trip to the shore and the every day use of errands and jobs.     Rating: 4

    2014-06-17: This Android phone charger spends most of its time riding around in my glove box, not seeing the light of day. Why? I walk to work most days, and when I do go somewhere it's usually within an hour's drive. However, we recently took a long weekend trip and needed to recharge phones en route.This phone charger performed like a champ. It fits snugly into the power socket in the car and charged our phones as quickly as they charge when we plug them into wall outlets at home.There are two improvements I would suggest, though these are not fatal flaws:1) How about an indicator light to let you know that the unit is seated completely in the power outlet?2) It would be really nice if the coiled cord was a bit longer. OK, a little more about this one...When I was riding along and trying to use my phone while it was plugged in the cord length was not quite long enough to reach from the power outlet, which is actually in a console between the front seats and my ear while seated up front. I gave it some healthy tugs and stretches, but it was still a little short but not too bad after that. It will take some more limbering up and additional stretching and then it may reach all the way with no problem.All in all a solid charger that does what it's designed to do, but with only minor issues.I give this unit a strong 4-stars

    Rating: 4

    2014-05-28: The Samsung OEM wall charger that came with my Samsung Galaxy S4 has a stated output of 2.0 amps and this Amazon Basics car charger charges my Galaxy S4 as quickly as that wall charger. This Amazon Basics car charger does get warm to the touch when charging, but all of the wall chargers I have used with my Galaxy S4 have the same problem. I previously used an OEM Samsung car charger, theSamsung OEM Car Charger for Samsung Galaxy S4, Galaxy S3, Galaxy Note 2 and More (Bulk Packaging), which has an output of only .7 amps and takes quite a while to charge my phone. So, this Amazon Basics car charger has now permanently replaced this Samsung car charger as my "go to" car charger.The coiled cord is stiff to operate, but it is long enough to be fully functional within the confines of my car. I highly recommend this car charger.

    2014-05-30: I have found the effective length between my phone and the car outlet is about 2.5 feet (30 inches or 76 cm). It goes probably double that, but 2.5 feet has been a very comfortable length for normal use. Using my Moto-G while plugged in works fine with the coiled feature, but you really shouldn't be on your phone while your car is moving (hangs head in shame). The only major consideration in purchasing the Universal Car Charger for Android is thus the length of the cord. I love the coiled feature as I'm always having straight cords get tangled in my gear shift, brake handle, etc. and this keeps things a lot cleaner. It also sits a lot nicer in the glove box which is pretty cluttered also. When I pick up my Moto-G it easily stretches for use, then gets compact again when I reholster my phone.So, I plugged in my Moto-G and the micro USB connector slid in perfectly yet wasn't loose telling me the machined tolerances are solid. Tugging the phone to speak there was no hint that it would come out and I could hold the phone up by the cord. It also pops out with a reasonable tug. YMMV since you may have a different phone, obviously. It charged my Moto about as quickly as I would expect, though I'm more likely to rely on this as on the go power and to keep my phone topped off.Amazon has these manufactured to spec in China, as with probably all of the AmazonBasics line. I have had zero problems with all of the Basics products such as USB cables, wall warts, etc. Simple product, good quality, works. That 5 out of 5 stars for me.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-12: The car charger works great, especially for devices that require more than the typical 0.5 A limit found on typical devices.However, the cord length of 4.9 feet may be somewhat misleading. While the coiled wire is welcome in terms of avoiding "self-entanglement", I found that the "recoil" on the cord to make its effective length about half that amount. When I'm trying to charge my Galaxy S3, I was fighting the recoil a bit and found the cord yanking out if I stretched it too long.To be fair, however, my phone is getting quite old (and heavily used) and I think the charging receptacle isn't what it used to be in terms of holding a cable properly. That said, I was able to use the cord to about 1/2 its advertised length with minimal fighting. I think that you'll find that with ANY coiled solution, but the buyer should be aware.With a 2.1 Amp output, however, I'd still recommend this.

    2014-06-22: UPDATE: 07/2014 PRODUCT HAS FAILEDThis charger failed during a long trip when I really needed to keep the smartphone powered up. Very disappointed. I had but ONE DAY remaining to be able to return for a replacement, and see that it is "out of stock" and not available for delivery until September?!?!?The LED went out, that normally indicates you are connected to a DC outlet in your car. Two other chargers work fine in that same outlet, and this unit does not work in any outlets in the vehicle (three were tried).The internal fuse of the unit is intact, has not blown, and there was no abnormal indication or use of the smartphone. I noticed that the charging unit had failed when the phone's icon for battery life remaining was far lower than normal.I limped along with the factory charging cord, which cannot keep up with both the phone in-use and charging the phone's battery.Although I'm glad Amazon's policy will cover a return and replacement, I hope the failure of this unit is not part of the China Syndrome of cheap products and poor quality control.Will update this review in a couple of months....-------(Original review follows. I had rated this device at four stars.)The higher power of this car charger allows me to get ahead of how much current the phone draws when I'm using it for navigation at full screen brilliance.The phone, a Motorola Razr Maxx, already has a beefy battery, but its extra capacity requires increased charging ability to bring it up to full.This device does that well.Car chargers with less power spend most of their time struggling to keep up with power demands of a smartphone that's being used. As a result, there's very little capacity left to actually charge the phone's battery, so it will take far longer than if you turn off the phone, or when using the somewhat stronger home charger.It's important to note that this charger shows no sign of overpowering the phone, which would present a risk of cooking the battery or burning up the phone's voltage regulator circuitry that governs the charging rate. Instead, because the phone operates normally, I conclude that this unit has the ability to supplement the power demanded by the phone, along with being able to recharge the battery.Recommended.

    Rating: 1

    2014-05-31: Car chargers at the big cell phone company stores are very expensive, so it’s good to have a basic alternative to provide a charge while on the go.The AmazonBasics Micro USB Universal Car Charger for Android has an output of 2.1 amps. The cord, when coiled, is pretty short (less than 10 inches) but uncoils to 4.9 feet. The charger fits easily and is easy to remove from my vehicles (I have used chargers that are sometimes hard to insert into the car’s DC adapter) and the other end fits nicely into my phone (Samsung Galaxy 5). It is built well and has a little light that illuminates when the unit is charging a device.Given the inexpensive price, I would certainly recommend the AmazonBasics Micro USB Universal Car Charger. If it holds up over time, this is a five star car charger for Android.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-29: This is a very good quality Micro USB car charger for Android and compatible devices with 2.1 Amp power output from a reputable company.I attempted this with multiple devices that accepts 'Micro USB' as the charging port and all of them readily accepted the power output given by this universal car charger with 2.1 Amp current output. My phone (Motorola Android based) My tablets (Kindle Fire and Kindle E-book readers) all accepted the charge without any fuss. Even couple of my Sony cameras accepted this charger as well. This ONE charger in your glove box will come handy for multitude of devices when needed. The unit does not get too hot when compared to most other brands I have used before which clearly tells me that the power conversion circuit inside this charger is efficient and not some cheapo linear IC 7805 with odd-ball resistor shunt knock-offs.BTW, The Amazon's price on this is very competitive. The best thing about this charger versus most other similar product from other manufacturers is that it comes with it's own coiled cord and Micro USB port which means less clutter in your glove box.Amazon is also selling a model with Lightning (connector) for newer Apple DevicesCheck this one outAmazonBasics Lightning Car Charger for iPhone, iPad and iPod (2.1 Amp Output) - Apple certifiedGood quality product.     2014-06-05: Every one of AmazonBasics' line of products come similarly packed in a plain cardboard no-frills box with minimal if any instructions and nothing more. No clamshells or fancy point of sale packaging and it really underlines their basic approach to the product delivery as well a saving production cost and the environment from wasted lacking materials.However, one should not assume the product itself is lesser in quality and indeed this micro USB universal car charger is notable not only for is well thought out design but excellent construction and functionality.It's a single piece unit designed to charge android phones and tablets or any device using a micro USB port. Since it offers a hefty 2.1 amps it can charge aforementioned tablets at the same speed as your wall charger and even allow you to use the device as it's charging. The flexible coiled cable stretches from about a foot to four or so enabling your passengers the necessary reach to use the phone at a distance as it charges.So nothing basic about the product itself; it works good, is well built all at an insanely low price.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-25: I have a couple of car chargers for my GN3 that I've been using. However, at best, they might be able to prevent the phone from dying while in use. Why is that? Well the Galaxy Note 3 is a larger and powerful phone, which normally uses a 2.0 amp charger. Most car chargers either can't provide this or only work at full amperage with fruit products.So enter the AmazonBasics Micro USB universal charger to save the day. For my test and typical use-case scenario, I put my phone on my dash mount, fired up some navigation software (Waze, in this instance), maxed out the screen brightness, and went for a drive. Should also note I keep all radio's on at all times, including Bluetooth for hands-free calling, Wi-Fi, 4G/LTE, and GPS, of course.After about 15-20 minutes, the battery percentage had actually increased by 5%. Success! If this was any less than 2.0 amp, that simply wouldn't happen.Beyond that there isn't much to say. It's a basic charger design with a coiled cable that's just the right length. While it may go to over 4 ft, it was pretty stiff going past 3 ft. Although I already got that impression from the pictures Amazon posted. And for most dashes, this is more than enough. Any longer and you'll want a straight cable.Overall, I consider it highly recommended for any Android user - even though it will likely work with plenty others.

    2012-11-01: I really like this case. I'm a fan of Anker products because so far I havent been let down. They are fantastic cases for the price and this case is no exception. I love that there is an option to add the ring around the case. I'm not sure if they actually intended on using the phone like this but I have been using it with and without the PC ring for about 2 weeks. With the ring around the phone it makes it sleek and sets it off with the matte finish coating and the added shine of the PC frame. The reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because the PC ring is a bit loose on mine, its not really noticeable until you grab the phone and this could also be a defect with the case I got.     Rating: 4

    2012-12-03: I have had this case for about a month now. This is by far the best Iphone 5 Case on the market for price and style. At the time I purchased this case for $3.99! It was probably on sale but would pay the retail of $9.99 without hesitation.The case is great for the price but also for the style. It keeps the phone very slim and that is the point with owning an iphone. While the case offers a great look and protection against scratches and daily use, it would not protect against drops (in my opinion) on Concrete. It probably would depend how the phone is dropped and how far but a big drop I believe could still crack the screen which comes to my next point of getting a screen protector for it. I personally have the Spaigen T glass screen protector which fits perfectly with this case and hopefully would provide protection on the screen if dropped.A side note would be the headphone jack is definitely small and for example I use to connect this with my aux cable in my car and had to buy a new 'skinny' aux head cable to fit in the phone. If you have headphones that have a large connector it might not fit in the headphone jack.Overall amazing phone case and definitely recommend.

    Rating: 5

    2012-10-23: I received my case form Anker about a week ago and started using it the same day. The design is pretty straight forward, first you place the silicone (tpu) sleeve around the phone and then put the plastic bumper like piece over the tpu it will make a faint click sound to let you know that it is done properly. The feel of the case and look is great. There was no flashing issues on any part of the case so the quality control is there (for those who do not know what flashing is, cheaper cases usually have some rough plastic areas that arent smoothed down). I also dropped my phone with this case on and it survived the fall from a couple of feet. The cut outs for the case are great with 1 exception. The vibrate switch was very hard for me to get to. I have short finger nails and it was almost impossible for me to switch the switch back and forth. This isnt the only case out there that has this issue, and its to be expected when you are for the most part adding 2 layers of protection but its annoying none the less. If you are looking for a great quality case that has a few color choices and dont want to spend a lot id recommend this case over getting other brands like incipio or speck because with those companies you are paying 80% for the name, 20% for the product.

    Rating: 4

    2012-12-01: TPU inner case add just a little more protection than your standard case and the outer ring holds everything in place nicely. Buttons are very responsive even with the case on.Update December 8, 2012. Well, I had to send my first case back because of scratching around the protective plastic band. I just received my replacement case, and it has the same scratches. It looks like a combination of cheap plastic, and the tight packaging seems to mark up the band. Overall I still like this case but twice now it has arrived in less than perfect condition so buyer beware.

    2012-11-10: Was looking for a case that would give good protection that was not so bulky, well this case does both very well. As for the volume buttons those are very easy to press and protrude a bit more than the power button. I also dropped my phone in this case a survived the drop with no damage to the phone and should protect from normal drops.I purchased this case for only 3.99 with 5 dollar shipping! If you want slim minimal bulk, protection, good quality and don't wanna pay too much then this case is for you! I would make sure your headphone jack is a slimline design before you purchase!

    2012-11-07: After just receiving this case, I must say I am quite happy with it. I first had trouble deciding if the "bumper" would go adjacent to the iPhone or if the actual case would be against the iPhone first. It has the phone intact and does not seem like it will fall out at all which is a plus.One thing that is a drawback is how rigid the bumper is; I feel it could have been a bit more durable and gripped closer to the case but that could be personal preference. Also, the vibrate button is a bit too inside and kind of hard to get to until you get used to it.Overall, the case does its purpose and at the price point, it is a no-brainer.     2010-02-19: This is a pretty basic case that offers a medium amount of protection for the Droid.Pros: Fits well, not bulky, thin design, works well with keyboard, good grip and feel.Cons: Doesn't protect the entire device, expensive for what you get.Overall, I'm happy with it...this is the best choice I found that provides some protection in a form that you hardly know is there.

    2010-04-28: Fits perfectly and doesn't make the phone that much "bigger"My only concern is that eventually the case might just snap off. Not a big deal, considering I ride my bike to and from work and carry my bike up and down stairs, the frame might get hit by the bike in my pocket.I am glad I made this purchase.Perfect for people who want to have that extra layer of protection without sacrificing looks and size.

    Rating: 5

    2010-02-01: I have had my Droid since Day 1 on launch day and have been looking for the perfect case the entire time. I had the black silicone snap-on case from Verizon and liked it initially but fell out of love for several reasons. I finally stumbled on the Seidio Innocase Surface and it is PERFECT. Forget everything else, this is THE case to own for the Motorola Droid.PROS:- Perfect fit (no gaps)- Easy to install AND to remove- Provides extra grip around the Droid- Perfect cutouts- Durable plastic material w/soft coating- Does not pick up lintCONS:- AvailabilityThe best part of the Seidio Innocase is the perfect fit and solid build. The cutouts for volume, camera, power, microUSB port, headphone jack, mic, camera lens, and speaker are spot on perfect. My old Verizon snap-on cover covered all the buttons so it wasn't easy to always get a good feel for where the buttons were. My old case also covered all but a 3rd of the speaker on the back, which I never could figure out why. The Innocase reveals the entire rear speaker. The plastic snap-on case by Seidio is coated with a soft material so that it almost feels like a rubber case. I had Seidio cases for my old Blackberry Curve as well.I also like the top part because it's rigid enough that when I swipe the screen from side to side, the sides of the case do not flex. My old VZW case flexed so much that it eventually felt like it was going to fall off. The cutout for the mic is also done very nicely and I hope it improves the audio quality as I had problems sounding muffled with the VZW case. The entire case is also very easy to install and also to remove. I nearly bought theOEM Body Glovecase but read a LOT of complaints about how difficult it was to remove and how it added significant bulk.The Seidio Innocase Surface case for the Motorola Droid is absolute perfection. You can really tell that a lot of thought went into the design. It is also very slim and adds only the tiniest amount of extra bulk. If you wish you could keep your Droid naked, but don't want to risk it, this is your best solution. It's not a mil spec Otterbox case, but who among us really need that level of protection? Go buy this today, in two colors, if you can find it in stock.

    Rating: 5

    2010-04-08: I almost always have something negative to say about anything I buy, but not this Seidio Innocase for the Motorola Droid. It is the perfect design.- Takes seconds to install- Very, very slim design (almost looks like you don't have a case on)- Ports for everything (headphone jack, USB, camera, external speaker)- Physical keyboard slides out with no issues- Does a fantastic job of protecting your phone (dropped on concrete from 3 feet while working on car, and didn't even drop my call)- inexpensive- Looks cool- Non-slip, actually makes it easier to holdThe only con I could come up with is if you want to use a magnetic car holder, the case is some sort of polymer, and therefore non-magnetic. If that's an issue, then sure, go elsewhere, but otherwise, stop looking and buy it.(No, I don't work for them, I just love a well engineered product, which this is)

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-27: Nicely protective and with a good texture for holding without being abrasive. A little tough to remove, but easy to install.

    Rating: 5

    2010-03-13: When I recently purchased my Droid, I quickly found out how case-unfriendly it was. I started my case hunt with the Body Glove hard rubberized case. It caused a little too much resistance when sliding open the keyboard and it was very hard to remove the case if I needed to access the micro-SD card, pop out the battery to reset my phone, or place the Droid in a dock or cradle. My next attempt was the snap-on silicone case offered at the Verizon store. That case completely blocked my keyboard from sliding open. I searched the web for suggestions and all signs pointed to the Seidio Innocase Surface. I saw that the case had great reviews on Amazon and decided to give it a shot. Boy, I'm glad I did. The cover snaps on and off very easily. There is no resistance at all when sliding open the phone. Both pieces feel very secure and the case adds virtually no bulk to the phone (the Body Glove adds significantly more bulk, but does feel as if it would offer better protection in the event of drops). The texture has a very smooth rubbery feel and is a bit slippery. It's stylish but definitely not for the butter-fingered. The Innocase also easily shows smudges if your fingers are moist or oily, but they rub right off. I read the reports of top pieces popping off for some users. I have not experienced this problem and it doesn't appear imminent. My case seems very well made. Seidio offers accessories, such as car windshield mounts and desktop cradles, that work with the Droid in the Innocase. This is definitely the best case out of the few I've tried.

    Rating: 5

    2011-08-24: The case is a perfect fit on the phone. I seem to do things that would mess up most phones but this case is a big help to protect the phone. I have the clip to wear the phone on my belt and it is equally sturdy and works as advertised. I have other Seidio products(desk stand to use as an alarm clock, windshield mount to use as GPS)for the Droid and they are all very solid products.

    Rating: 5

    2010-06-06: This is a great case. Very basic item... simply snaps on (and stays). Easy to remove if you need to take your batter out. It is slim and doesn't "fatten up" the phone too much. Soft feel is nice.

    Rating: 5

    2010-05-13: This is a good case for the Motorola Droid, but it is not perfect. On the plus side, this is the slimmest hard case on the market for the Droid. It offers good protection from normal wear and tear, but I have not tried dropping the phone onto concrete to see if the case offers serious protection. All the controls are accessible through the case and I do not have any problem with the keyboard like some people are reporting (maybe depends on the size of your fingers or how you hold the phone).On the minus side, the case does make the phone noticeably thicker and bulkier. I used my phone naked for a month before buying the case and the phone does feel much bigger with the case on. On the other hand, the case is comfortable in my hands and easier to hold securely than with no case. Typing on the keyboard is probably easier than with no case because of the additional grip.Also, you cannot use the Motorola desk cradle or car cradle with this case on. Seidio makes their own cradles that work with this case, but theirs are more expensive than Motorola's (much more expensive for the car cradle). You can remove the case to put the phone in one of the Motorola cradles, but the case is not designed for frequent removal and I'm guessing that it will break if you do this very often. Note that you do need to remove the case (at least the back piece) if you need to change the battery or SD card.I wouldn't pay the original $25 for this case, but now that the price has dropped to $15, it may be worth trying if you're thinking about a hard case.Otterbox also makes a quality hard case for the Motorola Droid. It is reportedly sturdier, but also even bigger and bulkier. If you use your phone a lot in dirty or dusty conditions, the Otter case has gaskets covering all the phones buttons (though it is not waterproof).

    Rating: 4

    2010-06-21: Like others have said, I too have the dreaded scratch on my driodI've had this case for two weeks now and I noticed that my phone now has an inch long (but thin) scratch to the left of the verizon logo (only viewable when the keyboard is open) that was caused by this case. One of the tabs that hold the top section in place (lower left tab for the screen cover) is rubbing against the bottom section of the phone every time it is slid open to use the keyboard.If it were not for this problem, I would rate it 5 stars, the rest of the case is great.There must be a problem with one of the mold cavities (molds are multi cavity so they make more than 1 part each time the mold is used) and some people have reported this problem and some have not due to what I am guessing is a tolerance issue with one of the tabs.Unfortunately, have one of the bad ones.There are enough people now that are complaining about this, but not all, that is why I think they have a bad mold cavity.Good luck with your case!

    Rating: 3

    2011-01-08: This case looks the best of any case for the Droid Motorola (original) so far. It's small and light and basically doesn't add much weight to the already heavy phone, but as other people have wrote, it's kind of cheap and flimsy. I dropped my phone like a week after buying this case and it chipped so it won't stay on the phone. I used double-sided tape to keep it on the phone because I really don't want to buy another case as this is really the best one i've found.Edit/Update: After a few months, all of the little teeth/edges that hold this case to the phone have chipped off. I was seriously using double sided tape to keep it on the phone. Now I've gotten rid of this case and have a cute flower design one from LowerPrice USA.

    Rating: 4

    2010-02-26: Ok...so I bought a Droid a few weeks ago. I also purchased a Verizon snap on case with a holster. The verizon casing and holster are well made but more bulky. It was also difficult for me to place my Droid into the Verizon holster because it has to slide in exactly straight or else you won't get it in there. I usually had to use two hands to place the phone back into the holster. It kind of defeats the purpose of a holster if you need to use two hands. The Verizon model was easy to take out of the holster, just hard to put back in. When I received the Seidio and took it out of the packaging it seemed cheaply made to me compared to the Verizon model. I chose to put the Seidio on anyway and try it out. The Seidio case had received many excellent reviews so I definitely wanted to give it a try. Here is what I found.The Seidio case & holster is much sleeker and attractive than the Verizon model. The verizon model is thicker and heavier than the Seidio. The Seidio holster is a one handed operation which I LOVE! I can put the phone in and take the phone out of the holster without a problem. The casing itself feels great in my hands compared to the rough and edgy Verizon model. This case also has a larger opening for the speaker on the back of the phone. Why Verizon's model is cut smaller, I cannot comprehend so Seidio wins on that fact too. The design of this case is terrific. It is more costly than most of the cases on Amazon but I don't think you will find a nicer looking and more well designed model than the Seidio. Now if Amazon only carried Seidio's Innocase Car Kit..... I would be set to go!

    Rating: 5

    2010-02-26: Apparently, either Seidio dropped the ball, or Motorola changed the dimensions of the phone after Seidio created it, but whatever the root cause, the front half of the case won't stay attached. Browsing some of the forums, I see similar complaints. In theory, very nice, but the one I got just doesn't fit, and is being returned.

    Rating: 1

    2010-04-15: I really love this case. I bought it from Verizon with my discount for around the same price here. I like how you snap the case together and you can use it as a standalone without the holster and also just slide it into the holster if you want to use it. I just had one issue with this thing. When using the small face cover it has the raised edges at the bottom the length of the back and search touch keys.     2013-12-20: Worked well for me. Provided enough protection for me at the time.Like the soft touch material gives a nice sure grip.

    Rating: 4

    2010-03-29: Case was a real bear to get the front cover on. However it didn't stay on.I have read that some of the earlier cases had a "Fitting" problem that was resolved in later manufactured cases. I sent an email to Seidio and they sent me a link to a webform to fill out and upload a scan of the sales receipt. They have put a replacement case in the mail and hopefully this one will stay on the phone.The case itself is very nice. Fits very snugly and appears to almost be a part of the phone until you look closely. Compared to other droid cases it has a much snugger fit. I did alot of research before ordering this case. It was by far the highest rated, with the only complaints being with the front covers of some not staying on (like in my case). It would have been nice if they could have tracked down the bad cases and had them returned to Seidio so customers would not have to go through this hassal.Assuming the case stays on as it is designed to when I get my replacement I would upgrade this review to 4 1/2 stars.. The cut outs are all well placed for the buttons and openings on the phone for earphones and charger connection.One bonus it seems, is that a naked droid appears to have problems coming off of silent mode when the volume rocker is accidently depressed while moving around in your pocket. I have read complaints about this in the Droid forums.However, I have not had this issue, as I have kept the back case on my phone and it appears to offer protoection from the volume rocker accientaly being depressed while in your pocket. The case creates a recessed area where each button is.I would recommend this case to anyone with a Droid with the caustion that they hang on to their receipt in the event they get one of the earlier manufactured cases with the front covers that won't stay on.You can avoid this problem by buying directly from the Seidio website, but it will cost you a little more in price.

    Rating: 3

    2010-07-06: At first I was very pleased with this product. It fit my Motorola DROID snugly and works wonderfully with the other SEIDIO products like their docking station and car dock.Less than three months later, however, two of the tabs that hold the cover in place have completely worn down and disappeared. The top cover will no longer stay in place by itself. The good news is that SEIDIO offers a 180 day warranty. The bad news is that upon requesting a replacement, I had to wait 3 business days for a response to my request. I then have to mail the defective part back to them and then "allow 1-2 weeks for processing" after which they will mail the replacement. That means at least two weeks without a cover for my phone. And this for an item I ordered directly from SEIDIO. What I'm most concerned about is that, if this is the design of this item, I imagine it will suffer the same problem repeatedly, needing to be replaced every three months. While I use my phone frequently, I am gentle with it and the cover has not been removed since I originally put it on, so there has not been excessive wear and tear.A previous item of theirs (the docking station) I ordered from a separate vendor originally arrived defective. I requested an RMA from them and was over a week into the process before they told me they could not replace it because I bought it from an outside vendor. I had to go through that vendor because it was defective within 10 days of the purchase. That vendor was not Amazon, but I mention it here so that people can be aware of the customer service they can expect should something go wrong with any of SEIDIO's products.

    2011-01-18: This is a fairly nice case. Unfortunately it only lasted about 3 months until the little tabs the hold the front cover on broke off.     2010-05-19: I'm a case freak, I get a case for everything I possibly can. Some case are great, some so-so and some are worthless. This case is amazing. There are 4 Droid owners in my family and we all have different cases- but mine is by far the nicest, and the other 3 owners are looking for an excuse to break their current case so they can get this one (funny thing is that mine was NOT the most expensive case!)     2009-07-12: I've been using my Plantronics Voyager 510 Recertified Bluetooth Headset for just over a week now with my Sony Ericsson Z750a.I hear every one I call perfectly. The people on the other end have complained of hearing noise that sounds like wind or hearing a clicking that sounds like I'm driving over train tracks or a bridge - both when I'm indoors, in room with no windows.A couple of times either the headset or the phone has lost its connection with the other as I'm placing a call. But once I disconnect the call, they link back up and work fine.This is the first headset I've had that doesn't fall off my little ears. I use the smallest earpiece of the three it came with and it works really well for me. I can wear the Voyager 510 for 45 minutes or so before my ear starts feeling annoyed with it. Thankfully it easily changes to fit the other ear.So far the talk time and stand-by time have been really good. I've talked for a few hours without having to recharge it.The answer/disconnect and volume buttons are placed well and work easily.   • B006NYP61K

    $B006NYP61K

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-03-19: This is basically a plastic mount designed by Samsung to specifically fit the Verizon Wireless version of the Galaxy Nexus LTE. IT IS NOT A DOCK. You still need to connect a car charging cable and an audio cable to the phone to get decent audio. I give it four stars four what it actually does and what is provided in the description.There is a certain segment of hardcore Android users who are still crying (as you can read in these reviews) because Samsung didn't create a dock for the Verizon Galaxy Nexus that uses the beloved 3 "pogo" pins that are on the right side of the VZW Galaxy Nexus. Samsung did make a dock like this for the GSM version of the Galaxy Nexus and Google sells it on the Google Play store. Your VZW Galaxy Nexus WILL NOT fit in that dock because the VZW Galaxy Nexus is slightly thicker than that version because it has 4G LTE. Honestly, it's not that big of a deal. It's not that hard to plug in two cables and who honestly leaves their mount on the windshield 24 hours a day as an invitation for thieves to smash your window. So you'd still be constantly disconnecting the cables anyway unless you want a mess of wires running under your seat where you'd stash the dock while parked.The Nexus looks fantastic when in the mount, but getting it in there seems to put a lot of sideway pressure on the volume and power buttons so I am concerned about those eventually breaking. Getting it out of the mount is also difficult. You usually need to apply significant pressure through one of the slots on the back in order to pop the Nexus out. Maybe there is a release mechanism but I haven't figured it out. The windshield suction cup mechanism works fantastic and is very secure. I am glad I purchased this as it is 1000% times better than holding the phone while driving and it works much better than a universal mount.That being said I honestly would not pay more than $30 for this mount. But I'd take it over a universal mount which will lack the same connectivity options and won't be designed to fit the Nexus as this one is. I snagged a used one for $10 off off Amazon and it works like new.

    Rating: 4

    2012-08-14: so i bought this MOUNT. i know what a mount is vs a car dock. the car dock is for the non-US gsm versions.. it fits the US version but u have to mod it and if u dont do it correctly u are screwed. lolso my review of this is: it works.it fits securely in there - like a glove.suction cups work really wellsimple, easy to use, cheap.the headphone jack and the charging micro usb jack are easily seen and reached by cables..so many people grip about it not being a dock.. whats the difference???????? the dock - u plug the cables into the base, and the 3 pins charge the unit and u can still plug an aux cable.. so for this unit instead of plugging into the base u plug right into the phone. whats the big deal?ohhh yea - the car dock software. just go get one on the market?[...]done.

    2010-10-01: This is supposed to be basically indestructible. It actually got a couple small scratches when I was applying it. It doesn't seem to scratch now though.     2011-04-10: Don't believe the hype from this company about how your screen sensitivity is not impacted. I went to the mall and spent my 25 bucks to have them put it on my Captivate for me so that I'd have a beautiful bubble free end result. It looked good but the euphoria only lasted about hour.This is no exaggeration. It totally ruined the screen response. Both the home and back buttons at the bottom of the screen required multiple hard presses and I could no longer text accurately using my Swype. While dragging from letter to another I'd get "skips" which garbled the input. This was no better that the one dollar product I had purchased from ebay a week earlier. But it was far more aggravating given that cost was many times higher and I actually drive to the mall to have them put it on.My theory was complete proven when I peeled off this $25 waste and my screen sensitive was back to normal. The marketing machine for ZAGG makes a big deal about the strength and scratch resistance of this product. When asked, their reps are trained to tell you it does not affect screen sensitivity. If decide you take their word for it, just be sure you ask if you can get a refund if you are not satisfied with how their product handles that one aspect of functionality. As it stands, they only replace it if it get scratched.Otherwise, don't get near these people.
