    2014-06-07: This is a key chain that has a USB, micro usb, and Apple 8-pin lightning connector attached to it for emergency situations.There are no instructions to this product but all you need to do is push the strap inward and the connectors will come out of the Hippo's mouth. When not using the cables, pull the strap outward from the hippo's head and the cables will go into the hippo's mouth.The micro usb and lightning connector have a short depth which makes it extremely difficult to connect them to a micro device. If you have the Samsung Note 2 with an OtterBox case then the micro usb will not fit, the color part of the device (mine blue) will get in the way. If the plastic between the two micro prongs was V shaped then this device would work better.Once you connect the micro end of this device to your phone, you must be extremely close to the USB port, because the cord is not that long, so it is almost impossible to plug the single end into a USB charger. This device is OK in emergency situations but not for long term everyday use.The quality of this device is MUCH better than what the picture shows. The straps coming from the hippo's mouth, on the photo, look flimsily. In reality, they are not, the plastic straps are pretty durable.I love this idea, but the device needs a few design changes like longer straps and a V cut between the two micro plugs. As it is now, this product is just not ready for prime time, but it is still a decent device. If you think of it as being connector cables with a key chain then you might be disappointed. If you think of it as a key chain with connector cables then you will be pleasantly surprised in a good way.[sample provided]

    2014-06-14: I'm always looking for electronic accessories that actually make my life easier. This is one of those accessories.First, the pros: it serves double duty: USB --> Lightning or Micro cable; and it's a functional small key ring. Since I usually keep my car and house keys separate, I tend to use at least 2 key rings, and this could easily serve as one of them, which would give me a usable charging cable 24/7.It's brightly colored, so it's easy to spot in my bag. It appears to be well made, sturdy, and unless unusually badly handled, it's not likely to rip or tear. Should last awhile.The lightning attachment fits my iPhone 5S snugly, but not *too* snug -- in other words, it's fairly easy to plug it in. I have a case on my iPhone, and it fits fine without having to remove the case.It seems to charge relatively quickly on the lightning attachment -- not as fast as the original Apple cable/etc., but would work fine to recharge overnight. I didn't get an "incompatible" message, so my iPhone is happy with it.Cons: My only quibble with this is the length of the cable. You release the cable by pushing it through the hippo's "mouth," but even fully extended, you have barely 2" from USB to hippo and dual-headed lightning/micro to hippo. This means that you'll need to be careful where you charge -- I have mine charging right now next to my laptop via the USB port on the computer, and it's fine. I don't see how you could use your device WHILE it's charging -- there's just not enough "play" in the cable to allow for that. Just something to think about.This would make a nice stocking stuffer -- a novelty item that actually serves a useful purpose. (Sample provided by manufacturer for review with no obligation.)

    2014-06-07: I received this as a review sample and at first could not figure out how to use it. An illustration on the packaging would have helped, but with a little experimenting I found that if I pushed on the strap that holds the keyring a set of USB connectors will emerge from the rubber hippo's mouth.That yellow hippo's head is much more than a cute decorative element - it actually protects the USB connectors against dust, moisture and grime. The cable is flat (it's the strap that extends and retracts the connectors as well as holds the keyring), and is very sturdy.I love the fact that it contains both a micro USB and Apple 8-pin lightning connector. I have both devices, so one charging and synching cable meets all of my needs. I tested it as a charging cable on an iPhone 5S and a Samsung Galaxy Note 3, plus an HTC Droid Incredible. There were no problems with any of the three devices.This is not a cable that you would use all the time. It's there for those times when you wish you had one and then remember that do do - it's your keychain. One other thing I love is I have the yellow model so it's easy to spot when I sit my keys down. Yeah, some folks wonder what a sixty-five year old man is doing with something that looks like a baby toy, but I encourage them to think I am senile so they will move on without bothering me.Bottom line: this is an inexpensive way to always have a synching and charging cable handy if your device uses either micro USB or Apple lightning connectors (or both). Plus you have a choice of colors.

    2014-06-11: I love this hippo usb cable. I can charge either my sons ipod, my iphone or my kindle fire, without having three different cords laying around.     Rating: 5

    2014-06-18: The Zeetron Hippo Compact USB cable is essentially a 5-inch ribbon cable wrapped around a keyring, with a decorative hippo head, roughly 1.5" long (and so taking up about 3" of the cable, since both ends of the cable pass through the hippo), that provides a bit of protection and decoration. One end of the cable is a standard USB connector; the other end has both a Lightning connector and a micro-USB connector. Since I don't have any Apple equipment, I was only able to test the micro-USB connector.The cable does what it claims, providing a compact alternative to connect your device to a charging station. My problem with the cable is that it's quite short and the decorative hippo cuts off a significant portion. For normal use, you'll get about one inch of cable on each end, perhaps 1.5 inches if you really squeeze the hippo up over the folded over portion of the cable around the keyring. I've uploaded a customer image of the cable in use, connecting a phone to an external battery pack charger so that you can see.I tested the cable by using it to connect my external battery pack to my dumb phone and my smart phone. For that usage, it works very well, and it's a lot easier to carry around than the three-foot cable I'm accustomed to using. I keep the cable and the battery pack in my backpack and often find myself using them on the bus home from work. The hippo cable has now become my cable of choice for this activity.The problem with the cable, and the reason that it doesn't get a higher rating, is that the scenarios I can use it for are pretty limited:- I can't use it on the USB ports on my primary computer since I'd have to find some way to prop up the device I'm charging high enough to reach.- I can't use it to plug into my charger plug on the wall for the same reason.- I can sort of use it to plug into the charging port on my six-outlet extension cord with dual-USB charging port but that would mean putting the device on the floor, which isn't where I want it. (And knowing my clumsiness and forgetfulness, that would be a recipe for disaster.)- I can sort of use it in the car but only if I'm willing to prop the device up at an odd angle and not use the device while it's charging (assuming I'm the passenger, of course).- I can sort of use it plugged into my laptop but then can't really use the device well while it's charging.All of these other scenarios work just fine with a 3-foot USB to micro-USB cable. For my purposes, the only place I can use this is to connect my external battery pack to my phone. For that use, it's great and it's easier to carry around than what I was using. If that's your primary use or you just need an emergency backup, then I can definitely recommend this, as it seems sturdy and it works well. If you need something more flexible, I recommend looking elsewhere.Disclaimer: The manufacturer provided a sample for review purposes with no restrictions on the review outcome. I have no personal or financial interest in the company or in anyone employed there.

    Rating: 3

    2014-06-28: This is a very cute product that should appeal to secondary school kids as they travel with technology and need a quick way to plug in their phone to their laptop, tablet or power bank. For the rest of us, it seems to work well but the short length of the doubled-over cable limits practical use.Tested with my son's HTC Droid DNA by charging the DNA via laptop and power bank connections. The USB and micro USB connectors fit perfectly into every port, and charging occurred as expected. No issue at all with performance, only with design.The unit's charging cable is fed through the hippo's mouth and through the top of its head, then through a key ring, and then back down through the hippo. This effectively cuts the usable length of the cord in half... but then the hippo's head sits over half of the remaining space, really only leaving about one inch of cable to play with.That was workable, though still a confined fit, when charging from a laptop port as we could lay the phone on top of the laptop (see picture). It was also workable when charging from a power bank, as the phone and bank can be laid down next to each other too. However, it was not workable from our USB enabled outlet or from plug-in USB power adapters as they all are at wall outlet height (typically 10 to 16 inches off of the floor or counter)... and the cable just can't reach.If you would like to see pictures of the hippo unit we received, please navigate to its main sales page and then scroll down to where the "Most Helpful Customer Reviews" section starts -- look to the right of that area for the "Product Images From Customers" section, and our pictures are there. It is a nice looking unit that feels good in the hand.The Amazon sales listing notes that this item includes a one year warranty, so if an issue arises within that time period I will return here to update the review and let you know what the issue was and how resolution was handled. I did receive this cable gratis from the manufacturer and have put it through the paces to objectively find out how well it performed. My statements here reflect that testing.If you are looking for a cute novelty for the tech savvy secondary school kid in your life, a USB charging cable of this size, style and design for use similar to what I have described above, then feel free to give this one a try. It is cute and it performs well, given the limitations noted above.

    Rating: 3

    2014-06-09: The Zeetron Rubber Hippo USB Connector Cable has a handy key chain on one end and two 1/2 inch wide flat cables protruding from the bottom of the Hippo's mouth, each cable easily bends and pivots 90 degrees to accommodate attachment to devices with a USB connector on one end and a choice of either micro connector or lightning connector on the other end. The cables are rather short but I had no problem hooking a portable battery charger using the USB head and hooking an iPhone to the lightning connector or a Kindle to the micro connector on the other end. As an alternative, simply remove the keychain and pull out the cable and then there is 6 inches of USB to dual connectors cable to work with. When not in use, the cable connectors can be pulled into the hippo's head for safe storage, which then lengthens the key chain cable end. A very unique, humorous idea that solves the problem of always searching thru a glut of tangled cables for either type connector with a USB end. And it's easy to spot, coming in 5 different colors. Highly Recommended. Five UNUSUAL Stars! (1 Hippo USB cable to Micro and Lightning connector heads. 5 colors: blue, pink, red, green, and yellow. This item was provided by the manufacturer for testing and an impartial review.)

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-22: This Hippo USB Cabler and Keychain is adorable...The cables are shorter than I liked them to be but it does the job...It comes with Lightening USB for iphones and a micro USB port for Samsung Galaxy or other android phones...It hooked right to Samsung Note 2 straight to my computer for charging...It's compact and handy to travel with and kids should love it...I received a sample for review...

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-08: This is novelty items, the cable length is not long. If it were retractable in nature with this design I would have given 5 stars. Nevertheless this is functional and unique design. Kids love this! Sample provided for a fair and honest review.

    Rating: 4

    2014-06-21: I am just now starting to become aware of the neat and nifty little travel cables & accessories available, starting with the 6" magnetic micro USB cable. It has quickly become extremely useful in my life. I thought this little guy was an alien at first, but no-- it's a hippo!The special thing about this guy is that you can slide his head up to reveal a USB cable that plugs both into micro USB or lightning-- it's a universal connector! Perfect for any time you are on the go and need to charge in places where you didn't expect to need to. I carry a flash drive on my keychain, in the same vane as this.The hippo head is quite soft rubber-- pliable and cool. I can't say that this is a great kids item because I don't know why kids would need their own, but it could also make a really cute gift. That being said, I'd prefer an alien. :)By a lot of hard hours and days and years of time spent reviewing, I found myself in the top 10 reviewers on Amazon. This wasn't a goal or self promotion, but by nose-down focused reviewing. I occasionally get contacted by manufacturers or sellers who appreciate my way of reviewing and ask if I'll consider reviewing a product for them, with no obligation or cost. This is one of those products. I assure you that I review what I want, when I want, how I want, in order to share what I feel is the most accurate useful information.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-16: Maybe it is just me, but a charging cable is not one of the things that I keep on my person throughout the course of a day. Sure, I keep a charger in my car; carrying a charging cable is inconvenient and could get damaged in a bag or pocket. Zeetron has thought long and hard about a way to address this matter and come up with a solution to make it more convenient to bring one along with you:A keychain hippo.More specifically, a silicone keychain hippo that "regurgitates" two ends of a single cable; one end has a USB connector, the other has an "A"-shaped splitter with a micro-USB tip on one end and a lightning connector on the other. The keyring prevents the cord from being pulled completely out of the mouth; conversely, the connectors prevent the cable from being pulled out of the opening on top of the "head" of the hippo.When you are finished using the cable, simply pull up on the keyring and the hippo will "eat" the connectors, hiding them completely within the "head" of the unit. The excess cable will sprout from the top of the head of the hippo, resulting in the head hanging from the cord and becoming a "keychain" once again.While using this product is very simple, there are a few issues:* Since the cable is folded in half over the keyring, you do not have a lot of room to maneuver between plugging the USB adapter into a power source and then the appropriate charging tip into your device. As a result, you are limited to using this as a charger with USB ports that are near flat surfaces. Otherwise, your phone/device will be dangling precariously from the charging tip, as well as pulling against the USB plug and the port that your "hippo" is plugged into.* Unless you also choose to carry a USB/AC Outlet adapter as well, this keychain forces you to seek out USB charging sources. You will either need to carry an adapter, purchase a separate external battery/portable charger, or be aware of what options are available to you at your destination.* Even though there are two adapter tips available (micro-USB and a lightning connector), you are not going to be able to use both at the same time. There simply is not enough room between them on the A-frame.Unfortunately, most of the issues above are pretty important. That being said, if you purchase the Zeetron Hippo Charger as an emergency backup cable, then this is a good choice. It is handy if you forgot to charge your phone, lost your cable, or otherwise find yourself in a position where you have access to a power source (bit of a non-sequitur, but I really do strongly recommend purchasing a portable battery) but don't have your usual charging cable handy, then you can whip out your keys and go "I have my Hippo!".So, in conclusion, if you are considering the Zeetron Hippo as a primary charger, you will be disappointed. There are simply too many design flaws to consider this product as your first choice for charging your device(s). However, if you are buying this as a [cute] keychain fob to have on-hand for one of those times when you need a cable and are nowhere near home, then this is an excellent product!Oh, and did I mention that it is pretty cute, too? This would make a wonderful gift for that techie person in your life that has lots of little gadgets and would enjoy something different for his/her keychain!**Disclaimer: This hippo was sent to me by the manufacturer at no cost to review. While I do not feel that this influenced me in any capacity, I am legally obligated to disclose this fact so that you can come to your own conclusions about the merit of this analysis.**

    Rating: 4

    2014-06-08: Pretty dang cute! This would make a great gift or stocking stuffer!The rubbery hippo keeps the charging end clean and protected when not in use. The entire cord is pretty short so you need an outlet that is close to a counter top or surface for laying your electronic on to charge. And longer might be nice but the point of this is that you can use it as a keychain and it is then accessible and easy to have on hand. I really like that.Works for my iPad. It even works for my Virgin Mobile Cell phone.

    Rating: 5

    2014-06-09: This is a cute approach to carrying around a USB cable for those "just in case" situations... the Zeetron Hippo Rubber Compact 2-in-1 USB cable. I personally am not going to switch my keys over to this (I'm not a hippo-kinda guy), but I can see this being a great option for kids who might need a charging cable.The feature that makes this outstanding to me is that it has both a Lightning and micro-USB connector built into the plug. So in my case, one cable would serve both my iPhone 5S and my Kindle. The two ends of the USB cable are covered by the hippo head, and sliding the head down the cable exposes the two plugs. The rubber is pretty flexible, so it's not that difficult to work the plugs through the "mouth" of the hippo for use.The main down side is the length of the cable. The cable is about four inches, so there's two inches on each side once it's linked through the keyring. With the hippo head pushed up to the keyring, the effective overall length of the cable is about two inches, so you're going to have to be right next to the computer or power outlet to use it. Still, it's better than being completely without a cable when you desperately need to connect to a computer to synch up or recharge.For the price and looks, the Hippo cable is a pretty good deal (so long as you know the limitations).Disclosure:Obtained From: ManufacturerPayment: Free

    Rating: 4

    2014-06-24: This connector is useful and sweetly adorable. Who would expect that under a silly blue rubber Hippo head key chain lies a USB to Lightning or USB to Micro USB cable? I've already used it multiple times to connect a phone or iPod and each time it elicited giggles or smiles of appreciation by various bystanders of all ages. It's true that the cables are not very long, but you get about 3" by scrunching back the malleable Hippo head. This works under most emergency circumstances and it sure beats carrying separate cables around in your bag! This makes a great gift at a very affordable price!A sample of this product was provided in return for an honest review.

    Rating: 4

    2014-06-12: This is an inexpensive portable solution to not having a cable handy. With products that need Lightning connectors, inexpensive often translates to incompatible, and many cables of this price will cause your device to give you a warning message. This one works perfectly. The hippo part is not only decorative, but functional. It protects the connectors when not in use, and I can't think of another self contained solution that so easily fits into a pocket.I was most interested in the Lightning connector for reasons given above, but more of my devices use the micro-USB connection. That one works well too.The cable itself is short, and when opened seems to be shorter than it appears in one of the photos. You will need to keep your devices close together to charge. In order to get more than the minimum amount of length, I had to push the hippo head up to the point that it started to turn inside out. However, it's flexible and well made enough that it won't hurt it. On the other hand if the cable were longer it wouldn't work well with this design. It's a necessary compromise.Aside from the more pragmatic issues, the obvious selling point is its appearance. It's most likely the design that will make you want to get it, and if you like the design, you will probably like the product.Note: A sample was provided to me but no review was promised in exchange.

    Rating: 4

    2014-06-09: Very portable. A little finicky when plugging in, make sure the connection is solid, otherwise no charge.You can only plug in one thing at a time, but this also means you only need one cable.But really- super, super cute!I rcvd a sample for review.

    2011-12-27: I don't think this case is useless, but it is of limited use. This comes in two somewhat separate parts, the handlebar assembly and a removable case assembly. If you take the "case" off the handlebar assembly, you have to snap it back into place perfectly or it will fall off quite easily at the first bump in the road.That being said, if you make sure the assembly is secure, it really is secure. It normally takes me a few times of removing and putting it back before it won't fall off. I check this before I ride every time, even though I never take the case off. It seems like if I bump it just right in my garage, it gets loose again. I'm glad my phone has an insurance policy.I can operate my phone somewhat through the plastic, but it is hard to do when you're riding. I mostly wanted it to display my runkeeper stats while cycling, so that's not a problem for me. The ball joint is adjustable so I haven't had a major problem with glare (a little is to be expected).Overall a good case. I wish the case assembly and handlebar assembly were a single piece, but I guess I can see where others would want to remove the whole case when parking their bikes (personally, I just take the phone out).

    2014-05-14: If you're looking for a protective case that is great for everyday use and also for travel then this is the case for you. The case is really a "system" with 3 components: 1) a thin rubberized case that is not much bigger than the phone, 2) a kickstand back that dovetails and fits perfectly with the rubberized case, and 3) a rugged belt clip housing that the first two items snaps into.The rubberized case could be used by itself for lightweight protection. The only weakness here is that the corners are "thin" because that how it integrates with the kickstand back. But if you don't drop your phone a lot this could be all you need.The kickstand back adds a lot more protection to the corners, it provides a solid back and of course it gives you a kickstand capability, only in landscape mode however. I use it often as I read a lot of news and watch video on my phone so it's very handy.For travel, put the above combination in the belt clip housing. The phone goes in display-first against the solid back that has a nice felt lining - very nice touch! It locks in securely to a notch on the kickstand and has a heavy duty belt clip that rotates 90 degrees.Overall its a very clever system, solid and well-built, that has 3 options depending on the protection and features you need.

    2005-12-18: Guys,I have used several of my friends bluetooth headsets (motorolas and jabras) and had decided I didn't want one. Then I found the Mobile Freedom and read the reviews. It's quiet in the wind, it's battery lasts for days for me, it's easy to use, easy to pair and the sound quality is awesome!! Nobody could ever tell I was using a headset. It takes a bit to get used to the ear clip, but once you do there are no problems. It may be a bit heavier and larger than some, but then those little tiny ones that look so chic also have TERRIBLE reviews and TERRIBLE performance!! Try it out, you won't regret it.

    2006-06-27: I get significant transmission static with this headset with my I-mate Sp3i unless I point the phone directly at the headset from a few feed away. It has static if I put the phone in my shirt pocket! Since I haven't done a baseline test of the phone with other bluetooth headsets, I can't say if it is the headset or the phone, but either way, if you buy one of these and have the same problem, make sure and return it within the return period.Another problem is the plastic ear holder (the part that holds the headset to your ear). This is a bad design and honestly, there is no way to get this thing to properly and confortably fit my ear. The only way to wear it is to have half your ear lobe hanging out, which result in a lot of pain within 10min or so. Avoid this headset if you want wear a headset for extended periods of time.A final note: The wind blocking technology works well, but at the expense of a high quality sound transmission to your recipent. I've asked a few of my techno-geek-friends when I'm talking to them with the headset, and they all say that the sound quality seems to be missing a full dynamic range.Good luck!

    2005-04-12: i had bought the motorola HS820 before this one for $80. i have a motorola V505 from at&t.; the motorola worked pretty well, but i thought $80 for a bluetooth headset was way too much. i returned the motorola and picked up the logitech instead and for 1/2 the cost, i was just as happy.it fits a little awkwardly on my ear, but so did the motorola, so i am thinking my ears are the problem. call clarity and voice recognition is good. battery life is good. weight on ear is good. overall, i am pretty impressed!i wish there was some way to adjust the tightness of the earpiece as it feels kind of loose on my ear. would also be nice if the "on" button wasn't so small that you covered it up with your finger when you turned it on, making it hard to see the flashing blue light.whenever i use my microwave, it makes the bluetooth connection drop. just warning ya'. ;)

    Rating: 4

    2005-08-10: I've been using this headset for a few months and couldn't be more pleased with the battery life. It recently had no problems keeping up with a four hour Skype session!It is also capable of pairing with multiple devices, so you can for instance use it with your computer at home and your cell phone on the road without having to redo the pairing every time, something cheap brand-X headsets don't do.Logitech was kind enough to supply a very tiny charger, perfect if you take your headset on the road. For those international trips, no problem: it can handle 100 to 240 volts and 50 to 60 Hz (translation for the technologically challenged: you can use it anywhere in the world, just get a cheap prong adapter)On the negative side, it's possible to jam the connector into the headset the wrong way if you're not careful. Of course the battery won't charge up and the light won't go on, a dead giveaway. It caused no damage to my headset, but the connector design could be better.I found this headset very comfortable to wear for extended periods of time. The volume is loud and the sound quality is very clear. People on the other side liked the sound quality as well.There are a few negative points that cost this otherwise excellent headset a star:* after 10 minutes of inactivity, it goes to low-power mode "sleep". When the phone it is paired with rings, it may take up to 5 rings for it to wake up and start ringing. If you press the answer button before the headset starts ringing, you will lose the call. If you want to answer right away, you can always answer on the phone but if you do so pressing the answer button on the headset will not transfer the call to the headset like it did on my Sony Ericsson HBH headset, but hang up. To transfer the call to the headset, use the appropriate menu on the phone instead.* The ring on the headset is an irritating, non-modifiable melody. It would be nice to have a few options!* The headset is fairly large and dorky-looking.Despite these few drawbacks, don't forget that this is a very capable, well made and reliable headset at a bargain basement price, one of the best out there. If you can live with the looks, it's a super deal.

    Rating: 4

    2006-03-16: the "behind the ear" thing just broke...I baby my stuff and treat it VERY lightly, and this piece of junk just fell apart!!!Very dissapointed!!!I should have made my additions to this review long ago, but Logitech cam through for me on this headset in a huge way! They immediately sent me a replacement of the headset, but not just a replacement, an $85 replacement! Then told me to keep the broken one, which I was able to fix with some Krazy Glue!Really incredible customer support...I will never hesitate to buy something branded with the Logitech name!BTW, 5 stars on the earpiece itself once it was repaired with the glue.

    Rating: 1

    2005-05-23: I'm a great believer in spending as little as possible on glitz,bells and whistles, and generally go for performance and practicality. Sound quality and features are fine for the price. But the unit is quite difficult to wear -- the boom is wide and boxy; the weight is unbalanced, as well. I could not get a comfortable fit. My ear is well within normal range of size and shape, but was bent out of shape by the headset.On the positive, wind noise and lost connections -- common criticisms of other BT headsets -- was not a problem here. If you don't care about medium to long term fit and comfort, or the aesthetics of walking around with such an large unit hanging off your ear, you may be happy with this headset. I wasn't, and am returning it. I'm going to give the Cardo Scala a try; if it's no good, I'll probably go with a Jabra, and spend a bit more money.

    Rating: 2

    2006-12-15: I've had this for about a year. It works great. Great call quality, no static. Battery life is real good. The only bad part is this looks like a part of a males anatomy and I don't really want that on my head. Otherwise great buy.

    Rating: 4

    2005-01-17: Let me say a few things:Buy THIS device. Here are the reasons:- 7-8 Hours talk time- True 30 feet range- Wind filter for clear talking- Small and comfortable, doesn't intrude your ear- Crazy price, huge quality- Warranty and reliability of Logitech!I've used a Sony Ericsson and Jabra BT200 and I would say the Jabra is much better than Sony Ericsson, but the Logitech blows them both away. It's faster to put on the Logitech and the range is much better. The microphone is clear and crisp and the speaker volume is loud and sufficient.For me, I used a Jabra A210 bluetooth adapter for a Sprint Sanyo 8100 phone w/2.5mm headset jack. It gave me BT on my phone so I could use this headset. The auto-answer and hang up depends on your phone whether it would normally do so with a headset or not. Works great for me!If you are considering a headset, get this one. It's what bluetooth technology should be like. It's so great that Amazon sold out... nice. It was $39.99 (where did they all go???)

    Rating: 5

    2005-02-22: I was a bit skeptical when I saw the price and read some reviews but I thought hey its Logitech it must be good. I was right this headset is very comfortable compared to another headset I just bought. The ear speaker is loud even to the point that I don't have to have it on the highest setting. The mic was the thing I was worried about though, so I called my friend's cell phone and talked to myself and I was pleasantly surprised with the sound volume and clarity. Also I haven't had any complaints from other friends I've talked to with the headset. It has been my experience that Logitech makes the best wireless devices for the buck and they didn't let me down with this one (second Logitech wireless devices in two month; I also bought their xbox controller which is definitely also worth the buy.)

    Rating: 5

    2007-02-23: The sound quality was excellent, but the earpiece is flimsy and irreplacable: terrific electrical engineering, poor mechanical engineering.I loved it when it wasn't broken. Even wind didn't seem to bother the headset much. The voice quality was great on transmission and reception. But the earpiece is incredibly flimsy and can't be replaced. I got a new headset the first time on warranty. The second time it broke I could have gotten a free replacement again but I didn't want the hassle. I have a Scala now that I've been using for months and I'm very happy with it, even though the sound and wind-immunity doesn't measure up to the Logitech.

    2006-01-18: I have used it now for 2 weeks with a RAZR V3 and I am satisfied it works as advertised. It was very easy to pair the headset with the phone. The sound is good even in noisy environments. The headset is light, confortable and fits well.My only complaint is about the smart button used to turn on/off, answer, dial and pair. The button is also a LED indicator. The LED flashes diferently (different colors, intervals) for various modes but it is difficult to see the LED while pushing and holding the button. After a few days I got used to it and now I know how long to hold the button down to switch on/off, pair or use voice dial.At $42 it is a good deal.

    2006-10-24: very cheap excellent value. the problem with most is their uselessness when confronted by windy conditions- this does a much better job than most. v simple instructinos, though it lacks the ability to switch easily between headset & phone & back.nevertheless at $35 or under, brilliant value.

    2006-11-14: Pros:- Price- Ease of pairing- Sound quality (yours and theirs)- Battery lifeCons- Painful for an extended time (10 mins)- Hard to tell if on or off

    Rating: 3

    2004-12-28: I bought the Logitech Mobile Freedom Headset (980228-0403) for use with VoIP on my HP zt3000 Windows XP SP2 notebook. I wanted to use a wireless headset and VoIP to make international calls, mostly from hotel rooms. This headset did not work out of the box for my situation. The Logitech support website was great. It said to upgrade the notebook's bluetooth software. The HP site was also excellent. I downloaded bluetooth and many other newer drivers. Once installed, the headset immediately worked as docuemented. The other newer drivers solved all the weird hibernation problems I've been experiencing too. I'm using Skype for VoIP service. Skype setup has an option for using the bluetooth headset for Skype only, otherwise the normal audio devices are used. All in all, installation was a bit of upgrade work but competently supported. I now have a VoIP connected wireless headset that allows me mobile freedom. Due to my usage, I have no comment on the audio quality or useability with mobile phones. The device apparently will not work with the majority of PocketPCs due to a lack of bluetooth software. Thus I only gave it 4 stars. However, HP does sell stereo headphones (no microphone) for most IPaq models.Update: 15-March-2005 Am able to pair with Axim x50v PocketPc. Has considerable static. Skype and other apps nearly unusable. Continues to work with XP well. Suggest Plantronics MX100I Stereo Headset for using Skype on a PPC.

    Rating: 4

    2005-03-15: Got this headset to replace my Jabra (which was incompatable with my Nokia 3650). Fit and comfort is extremely subjective but I found the Jabra to be far more comfortable (I would actually forget I was wearing it); that said, this unit is not uncomfortable (until after a couple hours) just not nearly AS comfortable or securely fitting.Very few complaints as far as performance. It was easy to pair with my phone, my wife's Motorola V3 and even my laptop. Sound quality is clear for both parties (recipients occasionally complained of a pinging noise with the Jabra) and the noise reduction actually works to eliminate wind noise. Battery life is excellent. The single function can be a little aggrevating (especially when trying to turn it off as you have to hold it down for a long time). The only weird and very rare quirk is occassionally calls will be interrupted with a strange sound that sounds like someone dropping a manhole cover as it spins on pavement - very strange, very annoying and fortunately very rare.Overall, performance is top notch, comfort is acceptable and value is difficult to beat.

    Rating: 4

    2005-07-31: I have been using this for a month.PROS:It is a good value. It works really well, and it lasts a very long time on a charge. The WindStop feature works very well. People have been able to hear me very well while driving and even while playing volleyball. It stays on the ear well but is not uncomfortable.CONS:The unit looks okay but is less attractive than some of the other high-tech units on the market. 3 of my co-workers have commented that it looks like I am wearing a phallic symbol on my ear, which is really not the look I would like to achieve.

    Rating: 4

    2006-02-10: Because I spent a lot of time on the phone, I am very particular about BT headsets. I have tried every brand of BT headset you can imagine, I mean EVERY brand. I was so frustrated to a point I was ready to go back to wired headset until I ran into this little guy. This is by far the best one, hands down. My most miserable experence was with Jabra and Motorola. I had a lot of connection and audio quality issues with those brands.BT headset designers seem to favor visual appeal rather than performance. I don't understand by most headsets on the market are short and stubby, in which the microphone is right next to your ear instead of your month. Having microphone that far away results in having to turn up the microphone sensitivity, which cause the headset to pick up everything including background noise. Lack of an effective noise-filtering system such as the one in this Logitech headset, you end up with wind noise, car noise, AC noise, every kind of noise but your voice. In additional, the close promixity between the speak and microphone creates a feedback loop for a nice serving of constant echoing. I lost count of the occasions when my friends and coworkers on the other end of the phone tell me to "get off your crappy Jabra BT headset" or "take me off your Motorola BT headset". I am amazed that people on the other end can easily tell it's a Jabra BT headset because the horrid sound quality.Onto this gem, the sound quality is amazing, by far the best of the bunch. The WindStop system really does work. Together with the farther extending microphone, this unit produce the best sound both incoming and outgoing. I know many users complaining about the fit, but it's really a fault of the user. As one reviewer pointed out, there is a "correct" way to wear this, and I think it provides an excellent fit and comfort.I can't speak for all, but I personally don't wear a BT headset as a fashion statement. I use it as a mean for convenience and safety, so sound quality and fit are top factors for my consideration. On that note, this is a clear winner. I wish product managers and designers at Motorola and particularly Jabra take note of that. Jabra (250 and 250v models) being the worst with it's behind the ear design and a heavy-trigger button is really a very lousy product in terms of usability and sound quality. I am sure customers that raved about Jabra would rank this unit out of this world!

    Rating: 5

    2006-06-04: Good reception. It fits OK on my ear but not perfectly. It seems sturdy. Price was better than most. The wind doesn't bother it much either.

    2013-06-10: This is a good charge cable, exactly the same as the original that comes with the Voyager Legend headsets. But it is not so easy to quickly replace on the spot if you misplace or lose it, as happened to me. On-the-street replacements from some retailers can be costly.ThePlantronics Voyager Legend Charge Cableis a good one, and the new magnetic snap-fit connector has proven to be a good one when attached to thePlantronics Voyager Legend Bluetooth Headset. The connector works well in that if someone bumps or jerks the cord, the headset will pop off of the socket safely, without damaging the connector or headset. It's reminiscent of the MagSafe power connector that is found on the MacBook Pro, which keeps keeps that computer from crashing to the floor is someone trips over the power cord.The shortcoming with this cord is that it's only 9-inches long, though that's not an issue for many. The price is OK for a proprietary cord that works, but there is a far better choice for Voyager Legend owners. ThePlantronics Voyager Legend microUSB Charge Adapteris a far better buy than than the original replacement, as it includes a 24-inch USB to micro-USB charge cable that plugs into the magnetic snap-fit connector. The product images show that it has a short tether, which allows the connector to be attached to the cable so that it doesn't get lost.I had lost my original charges cable when visiting a client site, and was surprised that many retailers did not carry this cable as a replacement. When I finally did locate one locally at a major cell phone store, it was at a substantially higher price. Lesson learned, the hard way.Compare both the price and specs between the replacement Voyager Legend Charge Cable here and the more versatilePlantronics Voyager Legend microUSB Charge Adapter. At the time of this review, this multi-function adapter only costs $3.00 more than the original replacement, so there are better choices available.6/10/2013

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-01: I have only had this for a few months, and it has developed an intermittent problem which has gotten progressively worse. At first, I was puzzled at the occasional lack of charging. But sometimes I'd have it charging on this for 30 minutes and check to find the time left was still as it was before charging. It has progressed to the point where it won't charge at all.I have cleaned the contacts with a swab and 99% isopropyl on both the charge cable and the earpiece. The earpiece continues to charge without issues on other charge cables. I tried this charge cable on different USB charge adapters. The problem stays with the charge cable.I've noticed in searching online that others have had problems with Plantronics charge cable, so I've ordered another after-market charge cable. It is working fine on the same USB charge adapter.

  • B00B7NAFI6

    $B00B7NAFI6

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-04-16: First the positive points of this phone. The screen was very clear, and the camera was very good. The performance was much better than a Samsung unit that I used to have. The memory and storage is very generous and sufficient for most users. There are a few items of bloatware on this device, but unfortunately everyone seems to include their own on the phone. The user interface is not the usual android, although once you get used to it, it does everything that other interfaces do.Now to the negative points. The phone would not recognize 32GB cards, not even 16GB cards. It would only accept 8GB cards. The card enclosure was very flimsy, and that might have been the problem, although I am not sure. The phone deleted a few of my applications after I rebooted the system. I guess that was the last straw. I sent it back. The positives of this phone are much better than other phones of the $120 range, and I am hoping that I got a rare dud. I could be tempted to go back and try another unit of this phone again, hoping that the other unit will not have the negatives of this one.Update for the second unitThis device has good telephone, camera, and display. The general performance of the computer part of this unit is very good - for things such as GPS, WIFI, mp3, download speed, and battery life. Unfortunately, there are a few rough edges on this phone. The phone does not accept some memory cards (five out of the six that I tried) . The camera settings are a bit primitive. The autocorrect feature of the email text is very primitive. These defects are annoying but tolerable. I tried calling the customer service on these issues. The one time that I was able to get through, the representative could not offer any helpful suggestions except to send the unit back. All other times, the line was busy.All told, this is a middle-of-the-line unit, and it is priced very reasonably - less than half of the known brands with the same specifications. In all fairness, even the known brands have their own flaws and rough edges. I am changing my original rating of two stars to four stars.

    Rating: 4

    2013-03-30: I purchased this phone in hopes to replace the smart phone I purchased while in the Philippines (Cherry Mobile Flare). The Blu Dash 4.0 D270a doesn't quite stand up to the performance of the Cherry Mobile Flare, but since the Flare doesn't work in the United States, it is a pretty close replacement. Overall I'm pretty pleased with it so far. But like anything there are positives as well as negatives with anything. Some of the specs provided on Amazon and Blu's website ([...]) are a little off. Not anything major but I will run down those and the minor negative points of the phone in this review.[website & amazon specs]:4GB with 512MB RAM; Dual Core 1GHz Cortex-A5; 5MP camera (main)/ 0.3MP camera (front); 4 inch screen / 480x800 pixels; Android 4 operating system; Dual Sim Card GSM 850/ 900/ 1800/ 1900 Mhz/ UMTS 850/ 1900 Mhz; 3G HSDPA (AT&T; only)/GPRS/EDGE/Wifi; Wifi hotspot capable; A-GPS support; SMS/MMS messaging; micro sd card support up to 32GBThe only thing I found to be a little off, was the main storage size of the phone. The phone reads in settings, and also in other apps I have downloaded, that the total size of the hard drive is 2GB not 4GB. That's a nice chunk of space for the phone, but I still put a 32GB micro sd card in it for more storage. The 512MB of RAM is not that impressive, but it handles most of everything I need my phone for. If you are the type of person that likes to download a lot of games, maybe it won't be enough for you. The Android version is 4.0.4 Ice Cream Sandwich.I currently use AT&T;'s Go Phone service and the phone had no problem identifying the network. I wasn't sure if I would have to manually enter the APN settings, but the phone picks it all up automatically. I've had another unlocked phone with Unnecto, and I had to enter all that info in manually which took some time to research. I use the second SIM slot for my Philippine SMART sim card. It reads it just fine, and is set to roaming (which uses the AT&T; network). The good thing is that this phone will also work when you travel abroad. I have not used T-Mobile with this phone, but according to what I've read, the 2G connection will work, but the 3G will only work with AT&T.; The fact that the phone also has the ability to be a mobile hotspot is also a plus.One annoyance that I've found with the firmware of this phone is setting up certain contact info and ringtones. For some reason the phone would reset certain contact settings I had made to default. The problem has seemed to stop, but it was irritating at first. Trying to set custom ringtones for contacts is also an annoyance. Unlike the Cherry Mobile Flare I own, Blu Dash 4.0 doesn't give you a menu in the sound settings to choose from your custom MP3's. You have to open them in the audio player, and then set them as your main ringtone for sim 1 or sim 2. I have yet to find a way to set your custom ringtones for individual contacts. When you go to set the individual ringtone for the contact, the regular ring tone menu pops up, and is all that you can choose from.Another downside to this phone, is that I haven't been able to find much as far as accessories go. I contacted BLU through their website, and they referred me to an online dealer that had some BLU accessories, but nothing for the Dash 4.0. It would be nice to have a skin or case to protect the phone, but they just don't have one out that I know of. Universal screen protectors are easy to find, so you can trim them to custom fit the phone no problem. I've also tried a few different headset/mics in this phone, and only the one that came with it seems to work properly. The others will work as a headset, but the mics won't work for some reason. I have not tried to use this phone with a blutooth headset, but the phone is blutooth capable.Battery life is not the greatest. If you are using the phone pretty regularly to surf the web, or download apps it drains the battery faster. Certain apps can also eat the battery pretty quickly, so I've found that disabling them when not in use is the best way to avoid killing your battery. When using the phone moderately, the battery has lasted through out the day, but usually by night, you will need to plug it up.Overall, I would say that if your looking for a dual sim smart phone that won't break the bank, the BLU Dash 4.0 D270a is a pretty good choice. Blu also offers other smart phones with better specs, but they are quite a bit more expensive. $130.00 was more than what I paid for my Cherry Mobile Flare, but I don't think that you will find anything in the United States this cheap without having a contract phone. Unlocked phones are nice, and offer you the freedom of choice with your service.Hopefully this review is helpful to anyone considering purchasing an unlocked smart phone.Update 4/6/2013 :Check the comments to see how to resolve the ringtone issue.I have also encountered a slight problem with sending MMS messages. When I attempt to send them I get an error. Looking at the APN settings, everything is as it should be, so I'm not sure why it's not working. I've sent photos through different apps with no problem, but attaching them to a MMS, I always get this error. Maybe it's an issue with AT&T;, but I will update if the problem is resolved.Update 4/7/2013 :MMS error resolved. I had to download a messaging app from the google play store, but it seems to have fixed the problem. I am finding out that the built in functions for this phone are not the best. But fortunately you can download free apps to solve the issues you might run into. I downloaded Handcent SMS and now I can send my MMS messages without recieving an error.

    Rating: 4

    2014-07-07: good phone, for child

    Rating: 4

    2014-05-02: great team at a great price, including cheap phones is one of the best, pretty hot, but because I gave it a really exaggerated use, but nothing that does not give any other.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-01: First of all, this phone is a very good value at about $120. You have a recent version of the Android OS, a wide range of Android applications can be installed, and the screen is responsive without lag.Here are the two shortcomings I noticed, which, if important to you, might be deal-breakers, even at this low price:Poor camera---The captured video is of very poor quality when using any decent settings (i.e. H264 at 720p, or even MPEG4 at 480p). Very blocky, low frame rate; it's as if the processor can't keep up with the data input (Yes, I did try recording direct to internal memory so as to rule out slow SD card: no better). Still pictures are OK, but tend to be rather dark and missing detail at 5 MP AUTO settings. So, you wouldn't buy this phone for more than very casual use as a still camera, and probably only for send-by-message-or-email video. I was also unable to get the flash to work with any camera setting, even under low light.Wifi might be on the weak side---When compared with many other devices, the indicated strength of the wifi connection was low. I did not suffer drop-outs, as far as I could tell (although when listening to streaming data, the buffer may have covered the problem). Often the web browser would seem to pause during display of web pages, so I have a suspicion that a wifi dropout might have been the culprit.If you don't really care about the quality of the camera, and you don't notice any problems with wifi, then this phone is a pretty amazing deal.

    Rating: 3

    2012-02-01: Overall, this mount is 'Okay'. It does its job. Like many people mentioned, the part of the mount that plugs into the cigarette lighter is not very secure. There are definitely some angles where the phone won't stay still b/c the part going into the lighter socket is just not tight enough. Car sockets are really not designed to hold heavy objects secure, so there is not much that could've been done about that. You have to angle the phone in a way so that the socket part won't turn by itself. No matter how you try it though, the whole mount feels unsecured and flimsy when driving.The quality of the parts feel cheap and feel like the parts will break apart when you are adjusting the arm.     2013-02-02: I had a heck if a time trying to find out if this case fit the upgraded version of the HTC One X, the HTC One X+. Even when I contacted Otterbox directly, they told me the best I can do is buy it and try it. I can now confidently say it does beautifully.Like all Otterbox cases, it does slightly increase the weight of the phone along with the overall size of the phone. Like I've told many people, your sleek, sexy phone doesn't look all that great when it shatters as it hits the ground unprotected. My big clunker though, survives every drop unharmed.I've had it on my phone for about two weeks now and have only minor complaints.Firstly, the exposed front facing camera hole can collect lint/dust pretty quickly. Same can be said about the speaker and camera/flash holes on the back.Secondly, the built in screen proctector does not sit completely flat against my screen. It's just slightly off of the screen so I have to push just a little harder to make sure the screen recognizes my touches. I don't know if it's because I have a defective product, or because the HTC One X+ varies every so slightly in dimensions than the HTC One X for which this case was actually made for.For the curious, the slight vary in dimensions is roughly 1/100th of an inch.Neither complaint is much a problem for me though, so I don't mind. The actual ability to protect the phone is what I'm most concerned about and this case does just that.This case is well worth the cost. I've never had a smart phone without it and can personally say that it has saved my phones on countless occasions.I highly recommend this product.*********UPDATE 9/25/13**********Well, almost 8 months and my otterbox is starting to give in. A couple of months ago, the flap over the charging port came off after so much use. The outer skin is now extremely loose on one side of the otterbox. The power button on the otterbox skin is now starting to loosen and tear making it harder and harder to power on/off my phone or to wake it up.Disappointed that the cover didn't even last a year. I like to think I'm not that rough on my phone.It has protected my phone on the few falls it had, so I will be getting another one....was just hoping at the price it's sold for, that it would last longer...

    Rating: 2

    2011-10-14: For $4, you can't really expect too much protection out of this skin. As they say, you get what you pay for. It looks exactly like the photo and does what it advertises, which is to make your iPhone look like a cassette tape. It looks great, but don't plan on this offering any bump or drop protection whatsoever. The material is flimsy and feels very thin in the hand. The case is easy to put on and remove. It wraps loosely around the iPhone 4S and adds a border around the whole phone that is undesirable to me. And as others have reported, there's no hole for the charger so you have to remove the case to charge. (I bought mine directly from CBUS.) The silent mode switch is partially obscured by the hole because it is not completely aligned.All in all, OK for $4 for the novelty value and laughs. I wouldn't recommend this as your regular day to day skin because of how thin the skin is. I'm afraid of putting it down because the camera is exposed on the back and the skin does not raise the iPhone off the surface.UPDATE: I've now been using this for a month hassle-free. I occasionally put the phone in my pocket, but worry about lint and scratches. For that, I put my iPhone inside aCase Logic TBC-302 Ultra Compact Camera Case with Storage (Black).

Now, there are some minor inconveniences, such as having to slip the bottom edge off to charge (no big deal at all) and the fact that it is silicone and can slip off the phone every now and again, but for the $4 I paid for it, I am very happy with it. I have several $30+ and this one is easily my favorite. It protects from scratches and I have no doubt will absorb much of the shock from a drop as well. I can deal with the minor issues for the novelty that can't be found anywhere else for this price!

    2012-11-13: put my micro sim in works in some phones does not work in iphone 2g the microsim is to thick i ended up cutting the middle out where the micro sim goes, you can find them already cut out for the sim to sit in deeper i would recomeend that

    2013-01-02: Somewhat works Most phones its hard to get my sim in and can sometimes get stuck which is not really good

    Rating: 2

    2012-11-10: Beware! These adapters are very flimsy and do not securely hold your micro SIM card. If your phone has a slot that the SIM card goes into (where you can't actually see the pins on the phone that will connect to the SIM card), then this item will most likely damage your phone. I tried using it on an old prepaid phone and not only did the micro SIM card slip out of the holder but then the holder became stuck inside the phone because the phone pins got snagged on the small circular opening on the adapter (you can see the circle in the pictures). When I went to remove the adapter it ended up bending the pin inside the phone which prevented any SIM card from being inserted. I ended up having to take the whole phone apart and bend the pin back into place.

    Rating: 1

    2012-07-26: It was expensive for what it is, but I needed it ASAP so I could use my old phone with a full-sized SIM slot with my micro-SIM card from my new phone that broke. I was waiting on a replacement phone and needed something to work. This product annoys me how it has "iPhone" in the title because it's for literally thousands of phones. This adapter will work with any phone, with any carrier at all. The only requirement for this to work with your phone, is that it has a full size SIM tray that needs to fit a micro-SIM card.Phones with a tray that slides out take a full-sized sim, phones that you pop it in and out like an SD card take micro SIM. At least this seems like a proper generalization to me. So as long as you have a tray in the phone you want to work, with a sim that is meant to be inserted into a phone, this adapter is for you, despite if you have an iPhone or not.

    Rating: 5

    2012-05-31: What more can I say? I needed an adapter to be able to use my micro SIM card in a phone with a normal sized SIM adapter... this thing does the trick! Pop the SIM into the holder and slide the whole thing in the other phone... you're all set!Recommended!

    Rating: 5

    2012-08-19: Works as expected. MicroSIM card fit in okay with no movement, bulging or other issues. Barely enough material used in the adapter to hold the card in place, so it is very thin. The device with the regular size SIM slot took it without any trouble."His and hers" colors are amusing, but this is primarily a functional product, so I don't care too much about the color.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-16: it is OK but nothing elsequality is medium and it can serve well if you do not need to take the sim out oftentherefore for one time solution it can serve wellbut if you tend to switch sim more than once or only very few times, then better think about something else

    2011-09-12: Great product. The Body Glove is much better than the silicone cover I had. The knob that fits in the clip is removable and can be replaced with a flush mount plug, so I replaced it. This matters because there is a variation in the bezel of these models. The original Galaxy S has a somewhat larger bezel which is coated with a chrome finish. whereas the Vibrant is a somewhat thinner bezel and the front facing camera is there making the location of or spots that the case covers important. Other than the confusing product line, that product is decent, and great for the cost.

    Rating: 2

    2012-10-20: I just got my ultra and its very nice. The fit is great and it is very easy to put on. I have an edge to edge screen protector and it didn't lift up when putting the case on. It's is almost exactly half as thick as the otter box defender I had on before and while there is not as much of a lip around the screen as the defender it is still large enough to keep the screen off a surface if placed face down. The pc and tpu fit together really well, it's basically 1 piece and nearly seamless. I'm not about to perform any type of drop test but the case is easy to hold and not nearly as slick as the plastic on the otter box. It looks great with the white s3, adds very little bulk to the phone but protects much better than most of the other minimal cases I've looked at. Overall highly recommended, plus the customer service is great!

    Rating: 5

    2013-03-18: I love this case for my Galaxy S3. It provides great protection, but still maintains a thin profile. Seems to be very well made!

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-30: In my opinion, this is a fair priced, good case. I'm actually so glad that someone took the time to design a case like this! It's quite thin, but due to the fact that it's two layers, the drop protection seems decent.I've been using the Otterbox Commuter for a couple months now, and just received this today. It's hard to say what I'll stick with as my daily driver after some time passes. I can say right this minute that this DBA case seems like what I'll roll with for awhile.I actually had the Incipio dual layer (forget the name) and of course dropped the phone twice, and damaged the corner of the case, which is why I went to the Commuter a couple months ago for better protection. My phone did fall off the fridge onto a tile floor with that Otterbox, but survived. But the size and the desire for a change up is why I bought this DBA for my GS3.I'm starting to ramble, but the point is that I'm quite pleased with this case, as it seems to provide decent protection, while still being very thin. It feels like there isn't even a case on the phone, but due to design, it seems quite protective.Also impressed with the design, cutouts, and overall quality of the case for sure. The only two very slight improvements I can possibly think of are: 1.) slightly higher "lip" over the screen and 2.) the cutouts around the speaker/camera/flash could be molded around each hole rater than one big cutout for all three. (But these improvements are minor).***Edit - I also just wanted to add that this DBA case is actually quite a bit thinner than the Incipio and the Otterbox Commuter I had.

    Rating: 5

    2013-04-24: So like you who is reading this review, I was reading reviews, surfing the net, trying to find the perfect case for me. Everyone has their own preferences. I wanted something thin, effectively protective (all corners covered), affordable (was trying to stay under $20-$25) and not some weird color. So after reading like 19 reviews that were rlelatively positive I chose this one. I liked the overall thinness - and overall the whole combo hard/soft type of cover appealed to me. The materials seemed pretty good and the matte finish was cool. It is a tight fitting cover but that was fine with me too. And I even dropped it maybe once about 1.5 ft off the ground and it protected the phone fine. However, there are times that you will want to open the back. I for one like the option to exchange batteries. I even take the microSD card out time to time for different reasons. My phone developed a crack right at the corner and I believe that it developed because I took the case off maybe a dozen times in the first month. Now, I thought I was being careful when I took off the case and maybe there is a more effective technique that avoids bending or something like that - but the case is a bit tight as others have called out. Last, I know for a fact that the impact on the ground had nothing to do with the corner because it didn't land anywhere near that corner, the impact occurred weeks prior to the crack developing and my explanation above makes sense. I would not purchase this one again simply due to the fact that I don't think it is flexible enough to be removed at the frequency I'm looking for....

    Rating: 3

I've had no issues with it cracking or snapping like some have reported.So far, my only complaint is the orientation of the 30-pin connector. There's no marker on it to tell you which end is up and that can create confusion as it's a tight fitting connection (also good as it doesn't fall out). That's the ONLY reason for 4 stars and not 5. But it's so minor of an issue!I fixed that by scratching into the plastic housing which end was up so it makes it easier to plug and go.All in all, I've very satisfied and happy with my purchase.

I'm not only giving back the star I took away but adding two because this screen saved me over $200.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-25: I've tried plastic covers for my phones - they go to pot very quickly, never feel as good as the glass itself, and don't seem to protect all that well either. They scuff too easily and you have to replace them too much.Enter the tempered glass protector. I've searched around and for the money, this is the deal to beat. The glass covering feels JUST like the phone and if anything is more oleophobic (harder to leave finger prints). It's also THICK! It actually stands proud of the S5 button just slightly. Thankfully it's not so thick that it comes up past my case. It really feels like it's going to protect the glass.You MUST clean your phone very and apply this in near-dust free conditions. If you have static electricity buildup, you will have a bad time. Both the adhesive and your phone will draw dust. You may even want to do it in a humid room (bathroom after a shower) and perhaps a grounding strap - to make sure the dust is damped.Even under fantastic conditions I got two tiny spots (thankfully at the very edge of the protector) from dust. You have to look close to see them, but understand that application is unforgiving. Once on, the screen is absolutely crystal clear and you can't tell it's on.Some may not like that the center button is no longer proud of the screen - so keep that in mind as well. Definitely high marks for this one.

My daughter's Samsung Appeal phone and my kindle touch got full charges. After that, it didn't have enough juice to charge anything else. But it was able to run the light for 8 hours.......which brings me to the flashlight portion of the device. Basically, giant battery and itsy-bitsy light. It's no Streamlight or even Maglite, but it'll get you where you're going in the dark. And the flashlight button is a tiny plastic dot that must be held for a second to turn it on or off. It is also a bit longer than the case, so the light can't be stood upright very well if you wanted to have it just shine up and light the room. There is just one brightness setting. So don't expect a whole lot from the flashlight.The only thing I would suggest to the builder is to rethink the flashlight control. Do away with the little button and instead use a twisting mechanism near the lens to turn it on & off.

I usually just need an extra 10-20% in case I forget about the charge and drain it while on the road in a car or bicycle.The outside casing looks and feels solid - I don't notice anything loose or rattling around inside. I'm enjoying it so far.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-13: I bought this for my daughter, who is always away from home and uses the excuse "my phone died" to not answer my calls. When we received it, most of the wording is in Chinese. There is barely anything in English. It needs additional cords and power adapters in order to use. I found it on the floor. My daughter won't even use it.     2013-11-29: Great product for the price. It charged perfectly. The light works great and it's small but not too small to do the job. It shipped super fast

    Rating: 5

    2013-08-18: I bought their 2800mAH and their 11200mAH battery too.Both do not live up to their ratings, even when you consider the power conversion losses.For the Kmashi 2800mAH unit, I fully charged it overnight then put it on a battery analyzer, discharging it with an 500mA load to see what capacity it can put out (see photo).Voltage regulation is very good but the unit turned off (went into low voltage cutoff) after delivering 1394mAHIf this unit has 1 qty 18650 2800mAH cell inside, I would expect the mAH to be:2800 x 3.7V = 10.36 Watt hours * 90% conversion = 37.296 Wh /5V = 1865 mAHWhen recharging, current was limited to about 0.73A so it can take a LONG time to recharge (my charger is capable of outputting 1.25A). Even using my iPad 3rd gen charger, capable of charging at a 2.1A rate, the current draw was only 0.73A. I suspect the charging IC is just a linear lipo regulator so the charge current to the 18650 cells is 1:1 for the input current. If true, and if one goes by the advertised mAH rating of 2800, then at 0.73A charge, full charge takes 3.8 hours.Still a good price, and great for an emergency. Just wish it had more mAH output and charged faster.

    Rating: 3

    2014-04-28: Compact and awesome. Saved my phone battery but even more so has a killer flashlight that is super bright. Must have for travelling.

    Rating: 4

    2014-03-02: receive it yesterday. portable to carry in my pocket.lt can charger my iphone 4s fully.led torch is perferctly.in a word it is a very good emergency item.l am so glad to use it

    Rating: 5

    2014-03-27: It doesn't last quite as long as the 2.8Ah would suggest, but it's still quite handy. After checking out the firstt one I bought, I bought two more to leave in various places (bike, car, house).

    Rating: 4

    2014-02-04: The power banks being shipped this week are very different than those reviewed before. The part numbers are identical but the weight is listed as 80 g instead of 87 g. Instead of the set of 4 blue lights to show charge level, now there is just a single red/blue indicator. And now the flashlight cycles through high power / low power / strobe / and then OFF with each short press on the button. So it now appears to work more like those sold by Swift Gear. Two stars off for going to the cruder power indicator. It also is now always live at the output - as soon as you plug in a device it starts charging and the indicator works only during charging. So, does it still have a charge or not - no way of telling.So actually 5 stars if you have the old version, 3 stars for the new version. Adding a strobe light does not compensate for the poor indicators in the new version.The newer version recharges at .75 amp if your USB port can supply that much. It will provide up to 1.0 amp. Holds charge well so far. Has no problem charging low power devices like MP3 players to 100%. It charges my Kindle keyboard at the full .85A current while maintaining the voltage at 4.97V, a very good result.You can buy an inexpensive 7/8" cap at your local hardware that will protect the contacts and switch from dirt and false switch presses.

    Rating: 4

    2014-07-01: After using it once, the button on the flashlight got stuck on -- meaning the light is stuck on and it drains power, only working when it's plugged in. That makes this completely useless as a backup.Although the shape and color are nice, it's actually quite large and heavy. If you want an extra battery, I recommend one of real quality, because you aren't saving yourself anything by going with this failure.

    Rating: 1

    2013-07-12: love it use the flaslight almost as much as the battery backup have charged my phone several times with it

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-29: Mechanically, thisKMASHI 2800mAh Flashlight Portable Power Bank(KMAX-807) looks nearly identical to several similar products I have tested, including theSwift Gear 2600mAh external battery packandKickBot PB2610. Electrically, there are several features I like about this KMASHI unit:- It has a 4-LED battery status indicator (instead of just one LED for other units)- It has auto-on/off feature: The unit powers up automatically after you connect a load to its USB device. It powers off in about 6 seconds if no load is detected.- The standby current is very low at just 0.3mA according to the back of the box. That means it can have a shelf life of up to 1 year.- It advertises higher capacity of '2800mAh' vs. 2600mAH for other products.Upon closer examination, however, I discovered several minor problems with the KMASHI unit:1. The measured capacity is lower.When using a 5-ohm power resistor as load, the unit is able to deliver 0.94A at 4.9V, or 4.6W of power for 87 minutes. This gives a total output energy of 6.67Wh. According to my calculation, the internal battery has a capacity of 2250mAh, or just 80% of advertised value. In contrast, the KickBot and Swift Gear units' internal batteries were measured at around 2500-2600mAh (All capacities are estimated assuming 80% conversion efficiency). See the chart I uploaded to 'Customer Images' section for runtime comparision.2. The battery status indicator is highly non-linear.According to the instruction sheet, each of the 4 LEDs should represent 25% of charge. My actual observations were very different:- 4 LED = 90 to 100%- 3 LED = 71 to 89%- 2 LED = 51 to 70%- 1 LED = 15 to 50%- 1 blinking LED = under 15%3. The LED flashlight is relatively weak when compared to other units. Its beam has roughly the same brightness as that of an old-fashioned 2xAA penlight. The up-side is that it has a much longer runtime. The instruction sheet claims 72 hours, compared to just 10-20 hours I estimated for other two units.(Note: you have to press and hold the power button for 3 seconds to turn on/off the flashlight)Overall, this is still a good power bank unit to consider - if you can get it at a lower price than other similar products. I would have given it a 5-star rating if its capacity rating were more accurate.

    Rating: 4

    2014-04-18: Now I have to buy 3 more for my wife and 2 daughters. They all love it and always comes in handy.

    Rating: 5

    2014-05-30: This was a great buy at $10. It charges my Windows Lumia 822 phone fast. I have yet to try it out on my Nexus 7.

    2014-03-05: UPDATE: I used to have an HTC ONE (M7) and I purchased an HTC Car A200 bluetooth adapter, which worked great once I realized that you have to press the activate button every time you get in the car. Problem was, I couldn't get my wife's S4 to connect. So I tried the MPOW based upon the good reviews.My experience: I was able to make a bluetooth connection to both my phones (HTC and Samsung) but it would be hit or miss (mostly miss) on subsequent attempts. Press the button, bluetooth says connecting (for a long time!) and then either an error "no media" or just simply not connecting.With that experience, I wrote a review giving it 1 star and threw both of these devices in the junk drawer. I've been connecting via wire ever since. Sounds better than bluetooth anyway, I figured. But hooking up a wire every time does get old. So when this company read my review they offered to send a new device. OK. Very cool!!So the new device came and boy did it seem powerful. Lots of pop and buzz and engine noise in my stereo. Wow, I am no electronic expert but that is a shielding problem of some sort? Anyway, it did connect to both phones but I had to keep the volume low, low, low to avoid the buzzing. Not good.But since they were so cool I wanted to give it a full trial. I took the day off and then went out again to try my devices one by one (in case the buzz was some sort of cross interference since I had all 3 with me in the car that first time). Well, no buzz today; that's good. Unfortunately, I can't change my original review.Results are as follows:(1) HTC Car A200 connects every time. Even to my wife's Samsung S4. (Must have been some software update?) Push the activate button and tada, music thru the car system.(2) The original MPOW connected once, so I got out of the car and walked away to come back and try it again. This second time I got no connection. Going into bluetooth setting on the phone I pushed Link-CZBT03 and got the "no media" error message. No further connections made.(3) And lastly, the new MPOW was a failure. It wasn't buzzing and going pop like it was going to blow up my amp, so that was good, but it didn't connect even once. Going into phone settings just gave me a grey "connecting" - that lasted a long time - and then came back white without ever connecting.I see some people are 5 stars with a feeling that they purchased a good, easy to connect device, while others, like me, have buzz in their stereo, connection problems, etc. It's cheap enough that you may want to try it? Just be prepared to get a refund because there are quite a few of us with a negative experience.
