    2013-10-28: This Samsung Galaxy S4 case is a good idea, though some might argue that it's not perfectly executed. You will have to decide for you whether this product will suit your needs. Over the past month, both my husband and I have tried out this wallet case on our Galaxy S4 phones. I used it very little, since, as a mother of three, I already have my huge "mom purse" that comes everywhere with me. I have little use for a cell phone wallet case.My husband got a lot more use out of this wallet case, and enjoyed many features, though he ultimately switched back to his old protective case. This wallet case does what it advertises: it holds a few credit cards and maybe a *little* cash with the cards, though it was a stretch at first. The wallet doesn't stretch too much with use, but then, you wouldn't want it to get loose would you? No.For a "wallet case", it's very compact, though it will chunk up your phone a bit. That comes with the territory I suppose. I really like the color options, and the quality of this case seemed very good. I definitely trust it as a protective cover for the phone. The sound amplifying feature is a nice touch!So why the 3 stars? There were two aspects that we didn't really like: the buttons are harder to push. I wish this wallet case was designed with cut out spaces for the buttons, because the plastic covering the button made our phones much less responsive. Second, the price on this case is pretty high. They do deliver a quality product, it does what it says, yes. However, there are comparable products out there at a fraction of the cost.So, ultimately, you're going to have to decide for yourself: is this case right for me and my needs? If you can't slim down to a couple credit cards and little cash, then it's probably not. If you need a temporary solution to reduce what you carry with you for whatever reason, then this might be a good product for you. If you need a long-term solution for the same reason, I might warn that the forceful button pushing gets a bit tiresome.I admire this company's design and ambition with their wallet cases, I think the price is on the higher side, and I think this product might be perfect for *some*, but not all.

    Rating: 3

    2013-11-27: I got this case for my Samsung Galaxy S4 because I thought it would be nice to have an option to have credit cards and cash with me at times when I want to minimize the amount of things that I am carrying, like on a bike ride or a trip to the gym. I will discuss how well this case fulfilled that need.The case is constructed of manly soft rubberized plastic that surrounds the side of the phone and wraps around to the back. I haven't had the bad luck to drop the phone while it has been in this case, but it seems like it would absorb a moderate amount of impact and prevent nicks and scratches to the entire sides, corners and back of the phone. It does make the phone quite a bit thicker and bigger feeling because of all of the rubber and of course the leather card slot on the back, and it gets even thicker when you actually put cards in.The volume buttons and power button on the side are covered with raised bumps that give you a good tactile indication when you are feeling for the buttons. However, I had some minor problems with how the case fit around the power button. I think that it may be keeping the power button partially pressed or not letting the button release properly because many times when I give the power button a quick press to turn it on, it will instead read as a hold down and pop up the shutdown options. I haven't found any problems with the volume buttons on the left side however.The rubber sides of the case wrap around to the front of the screen and provide a raised ridge so that when you place the phone face down, the glass screen does not contact the surface. However, I had a problem with the wrap around portion happening to just bump up against the edge of my Zagg stick-on screen protector so that now the screen protector is coming off on the top right corner and along the right side. I have two other cases, a Spigen slim and an Otterbox Commuter. Both of those other cases also wraparound to the front of the screen and have ridge there, but neither them caused problems with the screen protector. This is not necessarily a problem with the case, but by coincidence, the end of the case edge just happened to be positioned right at the edge of the screen protector.The case also has an "audio amplifier" feature which consists a hollow tube in the molding that channels the sound from the rear facing speaker to an opening at the bottom right of the front of the phone. I was surprised at how well this worked. When watching videos, The dialogue is much more intelligible due to this audio channel directing the sound forward instead of backwards.Now for the main purpose for why this case exists, the card slots on the back of the case. While the majority of the case is made out of the rubberized plastic, the large flat section of the back panel is covered with leather-like material with a slot for credit cards. You can fit about A maximum of three credit cards in the slot, But that is an extremely tight fit. It's possible that, like wallets do, this level stretch out as time goes by, but I haven't had it long enough to do that yet. The size of the spot is exactly that of a credit card, so you can keep a couple of credit cards and a photo ID. There is a small cut out on the opposite side of the card slot so that you can use a finger to help push card out. This cutout is very handy because otherwise the cards will be very hard to pull out, especially when the case is new and the leather is very tight. However, I that it was harder to put paper money in the slot, because of the sizing. A US dollar bill sticks out kind of awkwardly if it is folded in half and put into the card slot, and if you fold it into thirds, it's easy to get the bill lost inside the slot and it can't be pushed out using the cut-out because it is so flexible. It is best if you can put any paper money in between two cards that are inside of the slot so that you can always get it out by pulling out or pushing out the cards. I still don't know if I would want to make this the full-time case for my phone, because the credit cards are visible and I don't know if I want to make my phone even more of a theft target. I still need to carry my wallet most of the time due to all of the other things I need to carry, so why shouldn't I have a slim phone the majority of the time. But if you are card and cash minimalist, this case would work out well for you.Overall, I am pleased with the construction quality and features of this case. I wish that it didn't push up my expensive screen protector and power button glitch is kind of annoying, but it's nice to be able to only carry one thing when needed.

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-15: Nice, Light, Convenient and it is the only wallet case that really makes sense where the card holder is outside instead of in between.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-18: This fit my S4 like a glove and protected my phone better than other options.     Rating: 4

    2013-12-06: I got the Pacific Green CM4 Q Card Case for my girlfriend's Galaxy S4, and she loves it. It's usually harder to find nicer cases for specific Android phones, so it's great that CM4 offers this for the S4 and in different colors too. The Pacific Green color matches well Amazon's product photos and looks great in person too.The CM4 Q Card Case replaced replaced a basic, thin, silicone one and didn't add much bulk over the old case. Most of the Q Card Case is made of a hard and slightly flexible plastic that wraps around the back and sides of the phone. There are holes to keep the USB connector, headphone jack, and IR blaster accessible, but the side buttons are covered up. The holes are wide enough to accommodate larger USB and headphone connectors. Over the buttons are raised, flexible covers that you press to reach the buttons on the phone. My girlfriend mentioned that the sleep button felt a lot more sensitive with the case attached, but she got used to it pretty quickly. The bottom of the case has a cupped cover over the speaker that helps direct and amplify sounds from your speaker. It works really, really well.The cardholder is a really convenient feature and feels very sturdy. It's made of a leather-like material with some stitching along the edges. My girlfriend likes how it looks, and uses the cardholder all the time to store notes to herself. It's also convenient for when she wants to go out with just her phone, a few essential cards, and no purse.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-29: I have an addiction to cell phone cases it seems. I've tried dozens of them in the quest for the perfect companion. Sounds cheesy I know, but think about how much you have your phone with you... Does it not make sense to want to find the best case?I used an otterbox defender for a few months and liked it, but I had two issues, first off it was really bulky but it protected the phone good. The second was it hung on a belt clip and I had an issue where the belt clip snapped as I walked around a corner and it got snagged on the door frame, busted the plastic molding on the case and the phone fell out. Now otterbox is sending me a new one free of charge but it still will have the same issue, a big case that you can't really put in your pocket.So next I looked for functional and tried the amazon basic cases, just the rubber case, tried an Sview and that didn't work well at all. Then I saw this one and I had to get it. I use my phone a lot at work to listen to podcasts and talk radio and one issue I have is the sound comes out the back. The guys who made this case put a sound deflector on it to channel the sound out the front. It works surprisingly well and I love it because of that.The other feature is it has a wallet built into the back. For me I could fit 3 cards in and that was it. Not enough for me to ditch my wallet and carry this only, but it allows me to throw my company "grid card" in so when I need it I have quick access to it and a few dollars for the vending machines.The one other great thing about this case is the weight, it weighs almost nothing yet the protection is great. There is a thin lip around the front so the glass of the screen never touches the surface, the case itself feels really good and the buttons are covered but actually feel better to press in this case then without, and a lot better then the otterbox defender.All in all this is my new favorite case for the GS4.

    2013-11-24: My wife has gone through a few cases trying to find a keeper, and (so far) this is the one for her. Others have fallen apart (she's a little rough on such things), but this one is looking good so far. I will update that if things change.I have no negatives to list. This does exactly what she needs. It protects the phone's edges from damage in the inevitable drops and jostles. It has a small "cup" in the microphone area which reduces wind sounds in outdoor situations. It has a clever credit-card (or, I suppose, cash, drivers license, etc.) holder on the back, which securely holds the card in place, but has two notches to help you remove it when you need to. It seems like an excellent balance of security and accessibility. The leather back and stitching seem to be holding up fine. Highly recommended!

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-31: This is a great little case, even if you don't use the card holder. It's provides protection, is well built, doesn't add too much weight/bulk, doesn't block any ports, and has a great little feature that redirects your speaker sound to the front (so it's no longer block when you lay the phone down). It also fits snugly, yet isn't hard to take off. And of course it has the card holder. It can hold 3-4 cards, and again it doesn't make your phone too bulky.

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-21: I don't typically use a case, I actually think it is pretty funny when people buy the latest, slimmest, sleekest phone then put it in a tank of a case. I buy a slim phone because I want it to be slim.However, I also hate carrying my wallet with my DL and 6 or 7 credit cards, it is definitely a lot thicker than I would like. So on occasions when I go out for the night and I know I don't need all my cards with me, I switch over to a smaller wallet that only holds a couple cards. I've got a couple small wallets that I use for that purpose and none of them are particularly great.When I saw this phone case though, I had to give it a try. And it works great! It makes my phone a bit thicker but I don't have to carry a wallet at all! I've been very pleased with it, the construction is solid and it feels like it will last a good long time. It is pretty easy to insert and remove cards and some cash. The "feel" of the buttons goes away, you don't really get any feedback when you push them through the case's buttons, but they do in fact work fine. I'd say that is the only negative and it is relatively minor.I've got a black and a brown version. I thought I would prefer the brown, but find myself leaning towards the black. With the brown, the "leather" looks nice, but the brown plastic looks very "plasticy" and I guess that makes sense. With the black version, the black plastic blends in with the black leather and it just looks more high end.Overall, if you are happy only being able to carry a couple cards with you, then this definitely works very well and looks great.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-19: The concept of having a cellphone case that can hold a few of your credit cards so you can ditch your wallet is a good one. For my personal style though, I only use this wallet case a few days per month for my Samsung Galaxy S4.This case does add a bit of extra thickness to my phone beyond my normal slim case. This makes it just a bit too thick to be as comfortable for me in my front pants pocket. So on normal days I still use my slim case in one front pocket and my slim wallet in my other front pocket (plus I can hold more stuff in my wallet). I will use the wallet case if I'm going out on weekends and just want to keep track of one thing.Overall build quality on this case is good. Thus far it has been a very tight fit for me to put on my phone (not super easy like my slim plastic case) - but this may stretch out more over time. At $40 a bit pricey for my personal usage - overall I rate 4-stars in consideration of price/value.

    Rating: 4

    2013-10-30: The Samsung Galaxy S4 Wallet case is quite nice. I had a hard shell on my Galaxy 4 and when this arrived, I knew that I would be using the nice soft textured smart case for sure instead of the hard shell. The case fits very nicely over the phone. The extended buttons actually make it easier to use the phone buttons! This is most excellent, as the phone definitely can be a little tricky to feel the controls. This case resolves that issue. It doesn't replace your wallet, but can hold two credit cards comfortably and a 20 dollar bill underneath. So if you are in a rush or don't want to carry your wallet, this is a nice way to go. However, it does not hold three credit cards even remotely comfortably as it says it does. Too snug, the cards would be almost impossible to get out on a regular basis. But I put in my license, debit card and a twenty and it works fine and I can go anywhere without my bulky wallet. Overall, a nice looking case that has a few extras, the extended buttons are great, the holder works for a couple of cards, and the sound comes out very nicely. I definitely am happy with this!

    Rating: 4

    2013-10-31: The CM4 Q Card Case for Galaxy S4 is a really well made item that serves the purposes it claims to very well.It protects the phone (you do need to purchase a plastic screen cover separately), acts as a wallet, and the 'built in amplifier' redirects the sound from the speakers to the front for better sound quality.All in all this is a very good product, comes in a variety of colors, and is well made.If you are looking for a combo phone case/wallet then you need look no further.It is well worth the price, as the quality of manufacture and features it provides more than justify the price point.Highly recommended.

    Rating: 4

    2013-12-19: There are a few reviews criticizing this product saying that nothing fits in the pocket. However, it truly does, if you're reasonable enough to accept that you might only put one credit card, one debit card and maybe a folded over $20. It's not a wallet, it's a mini-pocket for the very bare essentials you might need when running an errand and don't want to bring your whole purse or wallet. Or maybe you're out for a jog or some other activity where you don't bring your whole bag of goodies along.The case fits the phones nicely, all the holes line up and it feels solid. I can't say I'll use it as my every day case, as I prefer something with a nice graphic and a smoother feel than when you have goodies jammed into a pocket on the back. But for quickie jaunts like I've mentioned above it's good. And it's easy enough to pop on and off so you can have a different "regular" daily case and only use it when needed.

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-19: The wallet case is great. It does everything advertised without too much extra bulk. The case itself has a high quality stitched leather look, and has held up well to frequent use. It also has a raised "bezel" that ensures that the screen is untouched when you lay it down on flat surfaces. All of the ports have plenty of clearance, and the button overlays are just what you'd expect. The little acoustic amplifier at the bottom of the phone works surprisingly well, and the wallet component securely keeps three cards comfortably.The only downside is that everyone can see your top card if you lay your phone face down on a table. Might make your phone an even more attractive target for thieves. On the other hand, you're less likely to forget your wallet if you don't have to carry it anywhere.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-04: As S4 cases go this isn't too bad. I generally use an Otterbox Defender. While I think the Otterbox is far superior for protecting the phone I have used cases like this the mostly protect the back of the phone while leaving the screen open. The cost of more protection is the bulk it adds to the size of the phone. I didn't think this case made the phone too large but then again its probably enough protection for most people, and lets face it any case offers more protection than not using a case.At first I thought this would turn my phone into something like a front pocket wallet and I could just put the essentials in it when I went out (license, atm card, credit card, cash). And yes you can get the 3 cards and cash they advertise into it. So while it does what they say I am going to say that in my use it doesn't do it well enough to be used like I wanted. It does hold cards but if you use 3 cards don't expect to get a lot of cash in there. With 3 cards I had to force money in, and Id guess that you could get about 4 bills in there once you fold them enough to fit and because of that I used bigger bills ($20s, 50s). Problem with larger bills is that a lot of times when you use one large bill you get back many bills as change. So money ends up in pocket unless you feel like jamming it in the case. Then if it is very full you sort of lose the ability to remove any of the cards or cash very well. The less cards that go in make room for more cash obviously Maybe I'm old-fashioned but I tend to want to pay for things with cash when I go out so a more cash friendly item would be a better option for me. If you just wanted to carry cards and you didn't need to have instant access to them this would probably work well. Personally I will either go to a front pocket wallet or just use the regular wallet as they are more cash friendly.It does a good job routing the phone sound to the front of the phone. Actually is does everything they say it will do so I cant really rate it too low but its not very useful to me so it had to lose a couple stars. The good thing is that most people including myself take their phones everywhere so you wouldn't need to worry about losing things. And if they make this with a money clip attached it would of been a 5 star from me but then some other people would of rated it lower because its "bulky".

    Rating: 3

    2013-11-03: I own two cell phones: a Samsung Galaxy S4 given to me by my company for business use and an iPhone 5S, my personal cell phone.Always on the look out for a good case to protect my phones, I jumped at the chance to try out this case for the Samsung. It's chic, simply put. Very light weight, fits my phone flawlessly and does indeed boost the sound when I stream Pandora. Buttons are easy to use; I never need to struggle to turn it on or adjust the volume. Where the camera lens is located,there is plenty of clearance so there's no shadows to the shots. Also a nice touch: a very tiny Micro-fiber cloth to keep the screen clean. NICE!!!I must say: I was the tiniest bit perplexed by a small webbed strap that came with the case; I had to look at all the photos to see if it was supposed to be used, but I guess it's not.I've read where other reviewers have chosen to use the open slot to store cash/cards, but I don't trust Fate that much! Plus, I never place my phone in a pocket...ever!, so I don't require something that will slip into a pocket. Therefore, since my Galaxy is for work, I use the slot for business cards, which is all I require of it. I'm too old to do the Bar Scene, so there's no need for me to have the skimpiest "wallet-like" purse to stow essentials away.For the person who rarely, if ever, has cash on hand and uses plastic 99% of the time, this product delivers everything with style. I, however, use cash 99% of the time so the lack of having a change purse or ability to handle more than a single bill or two, limits my use of it. Now, I know the war between Apple vs. Android and this product is designed for Android, but if Belkin could see fit to make this product for Android, I'd be ALL over it!Belkin Floral Wallet and Case Wristlet for iPhone 5 and 5S (Black)I actually own this for my iPhone and much prefer it for the minimalist touch. It has a very handy strap when you have NO pockets; it secures with a snap so there is zero danger of cards falling out, and there is a dedicated spot for multiple bills...I've actually had $100 bucks in bills in that slot with no loss of ability to close or use it. The down side is that you look goofy as heck if you need to make a call while your phone is in the case. THAT is the Plus side of the Samsung case; it's not much larger than your phone so making calls looks normal.It boils down to how LITTLE do you want to carry with your phone when you go out on occasions where "Less Is More"?

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-14: The case is of seemingly good sturdy quality. It is a perfect fit for the Galaxy S4. I do like how it looks and feels. Some have complained that the case should not have buttons, but I completely disagree. I think it having the buttons makes it easier to push the buttons - other than as with some cases having to fit your finger past the case to engage them can become very difficult - especially if it is a thick case.The fit is nice and the fact that it can store a couple of cards and money can definitely come in handy. However, I have to address a couple of design issues. One is the amplified sound that should be a big selling point. It was a good try and definitely makes it louder - however louder is not always better. If the sound is turned up at all, it sounds tinnier than normal on the phone. Makes sense as the sound is just being bounced from the back speaker and redirected to the front of the case. I could easily give it 4 stars on that as you have no option to use the amplified sound or not - it just is a part of the case. But, since you can always just turn the sound back down to fix the quality a bit, I won't. Also, I will add, I did find that you can download certain bass booster apps to help with that issue a bit. The other thing I would like to see is an added kickstand on the design. I am not faulting the makers for not having it mind you, but just suggesting it to improve the design. So basically just create a hole in the back of the case for the sound to escape naturally and add a kickstand and you will have a winner.

    2013-10-24: This case does exactly what it is supposed to. If you can cull out of your wallet 2-3 cards and a couple bills (cash) to live on, you can put them in this case, insert your S4 and just carry around one thing all day. Leave your bulging wallet behind! 2-3 cards would be your driver's license, Student ID and a credit/debit card.There is no getting around the reality that this does bulk up your phone. Any case will, but this does add a fair amount of thickness, though less than an extended battery pack would. Also, though the S3 and S4 have similar dimensions, buttons and ports have been moved so that this really only works for an S4 (time for an upgrade!).The real issue is... can people who are used to toting wallets, purses or bags with "everything" really discipline themselves to only needing a couple cards and some cash? This violates the old adage: Be prepared! I tend to carry my health insurance card, auto insurance, company and personal credit cards, etc. That won't all fit in here. And the other things I tote around (back up battery, Kindle reader) mean that I usually need a small bag. So while this does let me leave all that behind, I don't tend to do so.However! For a night on the town, this is perfect. And if I was younger and had less "baggage", I probably really could roll with just my phone and the items in this case.

    Rating: 4

    2013-11-21: This is a rugged little case. I actually got the green color and it is more of teal and I just love it. I have not had a cover that covered the buttons on the side before so I was worried about that...but it works great. The plastic is smooth and hard and I really like the amplified speaker part, it makes the sound travel to the front of the phone where you need it.     Rating: 5

    2013-10-05: Honestly? I bought my S4 months ago, but hadn't bothered putting a case on it because there was no case on the market that I particularly liked. And really, there was no urgency: the screen is gorilla glass, and my phone spends its life in my purse or in my hands, for the most part.The case the phone comes with is a flimsy white plastic. It's awful quality, I can't imagine why Samsung charges $600 for a phone and then ships it with such a crappy case. Of course Samsung probably expects you to upgrade your case as soon as you purchase your phone, and to that end the entire back of the phone comes off and is replaced by a new case.The S4 Samsung branded flip cover (with and without window)Samsung Galaxy S4 Flip Cover Folio Case (Black)is pretty flimsy as well. Plus the flip cover isn't particularly good at protecting the phone, so really, why bother.A number of the other options on the market seemed really bulky to me: OtterboxOtterBox 77-27604 Commuter Series Case for Samsung Galaxy S4 - 1 Pack - Carrier Packaging - BlackSpigenSPIGEN SGP Samsung Galaxy S4 Case Slim [Ultra Fit] [Smooth Black] Premium SM Coated Matte Hard Case for Galaxy S IV Galaxy SIV i9500 - ECO-Friendly PackagingWhen I ordered this case, I wasn't sure if it would be any good; a lot depends on how the product feels in your hands, and how the quality holds up over time.My opinion: this is the best available case for the Samsung Galaxy S4. It provides enough protection to the phone without adding so many security measure that the product becomes a bulky brick in your hands (like Otterbox); it has a sleek design so it feels nice in my hands (the phone is big enough already, if I wanted to carry around a mini tablet, I would have purchased the Note 2, not the S4); and the plastic is sturdy, of good quality, and not slippery. The small leather wallet part of the case is in the back of the phone, and is well made and sturdy. I do not expect it to fall apart, or become so loose that my card and ID fall out (of course it is leather, so it will loosen up over time, so don't over stuff it). Also: the audio amplification really works! The sound on the S4 is fantastic already, this just turns up the volume and keeps it clear. It's great that the case designers thought of this, because otherwise phone cases can mess up the audio of the phone.As far as color: the red is a very bright shade, I would call it "American Flag Red", to give you a good idea of its shade and vibrancy; the black is matte and professional looking.I would highly recommend this product; if your S4 doesn't have a case, definitely purchase this one, you absolutely won't regret it.

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-19: This is a fantastic case. It provides good protection for my Galaxy S4 and also looks stlyish enough so that I've gotten compliments on it.     2014-02-21: A few days after I ordered the amPen Hybrid Stylus here on Amazon, my mother ordered this pack of 6. I compared the two when she mentioned she got the pack for about the same price as I bought the single amPen. The lanyard/body is exactly the same (except for the iDream logo), and they both feature removable, replaceable tips (although I can't seem to get the tip off the amPen at all... hrmm). The iDream tip came off with a little effort.The tips themselves, however, differ greatly. The iDream tips are significantly longer and "grabbier". I can hear distinct squeaking of the iDream's tip across my tablet's screen and feel a almost reluctant, skipping resistance while scrolling, whereas the amPen has a shallower tip yet smoother (and noiseless) resistance.In the overall scheme of things, yes, the amPen Hybrid Stylus has a superior tip with every other aspect of the two being the same.... except I paid pretty much the same for one amPen as these 6 iDream. Regardless, I would still personally repurchase amPen's hybrid tip as the squeaking from this one got annoying very quickly. :p

  • B00337KT1W

    $B00337KT1W

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2010-01-23: I purchased this directly from Seido, and it's dieing on me repeatedly. The battery fails to hold a charge, even after many charge/discharge cycles to attempt to get the battery conditioned. If it ever works right (I pray it does, as I bought the Extended Case as well) I'll update my review/rating accordingly.As for it's look, I like it better w/the battery/case combo, as it sits better in the hand for calls, and the device now is able to sit on it's side for watching YouTube vids. Adds a little stand to the back of the phone,.........sweet.Like I've stated, I really hope the battery starts to hold a charge, I really need this thing.UPDATE: Download a widget called "Battery Left" (Thanks to Clay Kelley) and recalibrate the battery by draining and recharging the battery a few times. This should allow the Droid's firmware to recognize the higher capacity battery installed. I've increased my rating to 4 stars so far, as the current (past???) issue of having to turnthe phone onand off is a real PITA. If this works, that will be a DOA issue, and I'll go to 5 stars.

    Rating: 4

    2010-03-05: This is the 2nd extended life battery I've gotten from this company. One for my blackberry storm 9530 and the other for my Motorola droid. Both batteries delivery the same results. Initially, the battery life was about ..... "EVEN" at best with my stock battery, now, I'm a month or more into the battery and I'm charging it at noon time, just to keep the phone functional.I would avoid this battery at all cost because it's just not a very good product. I also purchased the external skin for protection etc and am quite dissappointed. Avoid and wait for a better solution.I would have given the product no stars but the review process wouldn't allow me to do that. Save your money and buy an additional stock battery. That will work better for you.

    Rating: 1

    2010-04-08: [UPDATE after several charge / discharge full cycles and learning more about this unique battery]I used to power off and on the phone to get it back into the green several times on one charge of this battery but I have a new usage strategy that is much easier. Basically I know how long this battery works on my phone first - it'll be 1.5 to 2.5 days if I don't leave the screen running alot. Now I simply ignore the battery meter when it drops to 5% RED on the first day because that is the lowest it can go (even though we know the battery has 50%+ charge left in it). The phone will operate fine at 5% battery with the blinking red dot. As time draws near for a charge based on knowing when it's really close to about 20% from all the experimenting when I used to power it off/on to get a reading on the battery, then I put the phone on its original motorola charger overnight. I always use the charger that came with the phone because it shakes hands with the phone and delivers more current than USB is specified for giving a rapid charge to full. The fact that it's taken way more than 1300 mAH from the battery and is at 5% will keep the charger going strong all night. The next morning it is at MAX without ever messing with the power button - just knowing about how long its been is sufficient to get the extra life and anytime you need to know for sure how much is left, power it off and back on for a semi-accurate read on the remaining power.The only time I cycle the power to find out what the real battery level is is if I am doing something critical or running a new app.This battery should not be drained dead-dead because it will be hard to charge (i.e. you need to power off the phone's radio with airplane mode and tap the top button to dim the display) - knowing when it is dead dead is hard too because motorola's "bean counter" approach to telling you how much life you have left is a bad way to deal with oversize cells.Should you find that you REALLY got your hicap battery down to a REAL 5% (by turning the phone off and back on while plugged in and getting a 5% or less battery capacity) you will need to modify the normal plug it in charge proceedure so that enough power is available to recharge the cell. Turn off the radio by using airplane mode. Force dim the display all the way down and turn it off once you finish. Kill any apps running that are battery hoggs (life360 for example). Use the genuine motorola cord and charger (not a PC or mac usb port) because they are designed to provide more power to the droid for charging than a normal usb port is required to provide. Now let it charge OVERNIGHT and a little bit more if you can afford the timeNext morning it will obviously read max on the bat, but all night long there was a trickle charge going into the battery which brought it back to 2600 mAh give or take. Leaving it connected will continue to add charge. All li-ion batts benefit from sitting on the charger beyond their "full" voltage simply because that little bit of trickle current does keep putting a little more charge into the cell. I have a 13,000 mah, 14.8V cell and a specially designed charger for it. From near empty it takes 3 days to charge where the charger goes "green" from "red".I don't use the last "real" 20% off this cell and I can use the normal motorola charging proceedures. The problem stems from the fact that the battery can be 20% or 80% full and read 20% on droid's meter in both cases (and one more in between). I have used it for 3 days down to 5%, which now I would only do in an emergency. If I'm on my last discharge where it reads accurately I'll be looking for an outlet at 50% and have it on charge by 20%.This sounds complicated but after a while it is simple and you can just charge it every night. Battery life is one of droid's shortcommings - this product gets you a full day and then some extra. At least droid users *can* pop in a fresh cell when needed!(below was my first impression of this battery having read how to use it and the shortcommings)Droid does. Yes indeed. Charging batteries is done by leaving the charging voltage on the battery for as long as possible (as long as plugged in) - so charging this cell is a no brainer.Droid calculates discharge. Therein lies the problem. Droid under "about this phone" --> "battery usage" keeps track of every mAh used and where it went. This is nice to see what apps are really sucking the battery dry, but it's also how droid knows how much power is remaining, and it assumes 1300 mAh is the battery capacity. But with this attached, 2600+ is the capacity.Example - last night I forgot to plug Droid in. I had charged the Innocell fully yesterday. This morning I was at 5 percent and had a red light. I did what the other reviewer said. Turn off droid and restart it (it thinks I swapped batteries, something Iphones can not do). Turned back on and I had 80% left based on voltage, not tabulated accounting of power used. Yes, overnight I used 95% of 1300 mAh, but I had > 1000 mAh onboard which showed up as 80% full.The next release of the o/s needs to have a field where you key in your mAh if they continue using the tabulation method of power management. As the 1300 mah cells age they will only hold 1000 mah and that must be accounted for. Also advancements in technology will produce thin 1500 mah cells which need to be entered into the droid. For now, this saved today because my phone is still running 30 hours since I last charged it. Anyone with a droid knows 30 hours is a long time on one battery!Cons: - the phone won't fit in the dock with this battery and cover attached. Oh well.

    Rating: 5

    2010-05-03: I have used this manufacturer's porducts in 3 or 4 different types of phones now - and they all worked great. Beware of other brands where I have found the batteries would not fit properly!Also get the specific charging unit for this battery and let it go through a few charging cycles to reach its maxoimum potential.Note: I have no financial interests in this company, and these units are not cheap. That said they do exactly what the company advertises - a rarity in today's market place.Jim

    Rating: 5

    2010-02-25: UPDATE 3-30-10: The Battery just stopped working after 2 months. It got buggy this week and just quit.2 months is not a reasonable product lifespan. My OEM battery I bought from Amazon is fine. I recomend purchasing the OEM battery. They cost less than 1/2 the price of the Innocell battery on Amazon.Origional ReviewI enjoy my Droid phone and with my usage, I go through batteries quickly. You can conserve power by turning off options you are not using (Bluetooth, 3G, Screen Brightness, GPS, Wi-Fi, Checking Email) I got this extended life battery and a spare OEM battery at the same time. The battery did have some of the initial issues that were described by other reviews but the battery eventually worked properly.The GoodIt is nice having one battery that outlasts the OEM battery. It was very frustrating to have my phone die on me and not be in a position to charge it. I don't seem to get twice the life from this extended life battery, but close to it.The BadThe battery does not fit in my Motorola car dock, which I use all the time. It also doesn't fit in my desktop charging dock which I also like to use. The additional bulk is not noticeable in a jacket pocket. It is noticeable in snug jeans front pockets.ConclusionI am happy with the purchase. I choose my battery according to what my use will be. If I'm going to be in my car I use the OEM battery. If I am out and about all day, I use the extended battery. It is nice to have options. I still bring my OEM spare battery when I don't want to take the chance of having a dead phone.Unlike our I-Phone friends we have the ability to pop in a new battery. ;-)

  • B006ZRYU9O

    $B006ZRYU9O

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2013-01-24: I used this while camping in the Idaho wilderness last year. Great product to keep our 2 way radios, kindles, and other devices topped off. It survived an overnight freeze with no change in use, though I wouldn't recommend purposely leaving it out.

    Rating: 5

    2012-06-29: This is my first solar powered charger, so I was not sure what to expect. My overall experience was positive, but with one issue I have not considered before using it.I am attaching a collage of 4 photos under customer photos that I will be referencing in this review.1. The solar panel is more compact that I anticipated. When not in use it folded up nicely into book-sized dimensions. Photo#1 and Photo#3 show the panel next to a ruler. Folded it measured 6.6" x 9", unfolded 19" x 9".2. The two USB outlets are located in a pocket inside of the pouch. See photo#2. The connection is attached to the pocket and cannot be moved. The pocket has a rubber band to hold something, perhaps a phone while it is being charged. The pocket was too small to fit my tablet which is sized 7.7" by 5.5".3. The third photo shows my tablet being charged by the solar panel.I used the solar panel to charge my Samsung Galaxy 7.7 table and Sansa Clip MP3 player. Both devices recognized the charger without problems and got charged.Now we come to the issue I encountered. I did not want to leave my tablet or MP3 in the full sun while charging them as sun exposure is bad for electronics. However the design of the solar panel made it difficult to keep the panel in the sun while keeping the devices in the shade. If the USB connector was not attached to the pocket but but rather was on the end of a USB cable then adding my own USB cable for the device together the longer cord would have been enough to easily position electronics out of the sun. With the length of the standard USB cable (26") it was a challenge to find a position that worked.Given my goal to keep my electronics in the shade I tried several options(1) On a sunny day I put both the panel and tablet in bright spot but out of the direct light. The tablet starting with 5% charge (i.e. practically discharged) the tablet showed that it recognized being charged but after 12 hours in INDIRECT light it did not get charged enough to be turned on.(2) I found a time in a day where I could put the panel in direct sun and stretch the USB cord in such a way that the tablet was out of the sun. I was able to charge it from 80% to 100% in about 3 hours.(3) I repeated the same sun for the panel/shade for the device configuration for MP3 player. Sansa got charged, but behaved strangely. Normally when I charge it from AC I cannot play it while it is being charged, the screen shows the charging mode (image of a battery). With the solar panel charge the MP3 player continued to play. I saw that the screen was not in the charging mode. I use my MP3 to listen to audio books, so the next time I used I found myself several chapters ahead of where I last listened. It did get fully charged while it was playing. The next time I had to make sure to pause the player manually before recharging.So overall it charged both of my devices, but I wish the design had a USB port on a cord that allowed more flexibility to put the device you are charging out of the sun's harmful direct light. I hope the manufacture reading this comments can improve the future versions of the product, in the mean time I have purchased USB extension to overcome this short coming.Ali Julia review

    Rating: 4

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-20: I ordered this as part of our back up system for a power outage. The idea was to have an off grid way of powering up two iPhones in a power outage. I tested my iPhone 4 using this panel and was able to get an 11 percent charge in 15 minutes. That equals a full charge in less than 2 1/2 hours. This is better than I expected. I was also able to charge an iPad 3 with this panel, but I have no rates of charge for this. After all, the reason I got the panel was for our two iPhones so this what I measured.Since I don't like exposing the phones to the sun, I also picked up two 8400 mAh batteries.[Upgraded Version] Anker Astro2 Dual USB Output 8400mAh Backup External Battery Pack Charger with built-in Flashlight for Smart phones, Android phones, PSP, GoPro; iPhone 5, iPhone 4S, iPad mini; Samsung Galaxy S3, Galaxy Series Smartphones; HTC One X ...] These can be charged by the panel outside, then I use the batteries to charge the phones inside when they need juicing up. Each battery is good for 3 complete iPhone charges and I can rotate the charging of each as needed. I also have a 4000 mAh solar batteryOpteka BP-SC4000 Ultra Thin Solar Powered High Capacity (4000mAh) Backup Battery and Charger for Cell Phones, iPhone, iPod, and Most USB Powered Devicesthat takes about 5 days to fully charge during the short days of the winter sun. Using this panel to assist charging my solar battery, has reduced the charge time to one day of winter sun.I was surprised at how small the panels became, when folded up. They have a total footprint which is slightly smaller than my iPad. The panels are surpringly light, and making them easily transportable and easy to hang from from one of the sturdy looking, fabric hangers. Another nice feature is a pouch on the back of the panel. This fits one of my battery packs with room to spare. This keeps the packs out of the direct sun, when charging. Inside the pouch are two USB ports which can be cabled into whatever is being charged, while in the pouch. Since the pouch has a closable flap secured by a Velcro fastener, your device has some protection from rain and dust. On a really hot day, it would probably be a good idea to charge batteries or phones outside the pouch in the shade. The black pouch could get pretty hot on a long, summer day, not exactly the best conditions for a cell phone.Things I like-quality of construction-rapid charging time-portability-2 USB ports for simultaneous charging of 2 devices-priceThings that need improving-access to USB ports is a little snug for big hands-the panels seem to scratch easily and could be more scratch resistantAll in all, an excellent panel for charging batteries and small electronics up to the size of an iPad 3.

    Rating: 4

    2013-01-02: This solar panel came in very handy during a recent extended power outage, when my iPad (with it's cellular connection) was my primary link to the world. I have a number of other USB chargers, both solar and hand-cranked, which worked fine with my iPhone but did not deliver sufficient wattage to charge my iPad. The Instapark 10 watt solar charger did deliver enough power to charge my iPad, as long as the panel was in full sun.The panel is very easy to use. It comes attached to a fold-up nylon case. There's a pocket on the nylon case, and inside the pocket are a couple of USB ports. Just plug your regular USB charging cable into the ports and your device will start charging (assuming the panel is in the sun).The panel charged my iPhone even when it wasn't in full sun. For the iPad, the panel needed to be in full sun. More importantly, if clouds pass in front of the sun, the iPad gets confused and delivers the dreaded error message saying it can't charge from what it's attached to. Sometimes my iPad started charging again when the clouds passed, but sometimes I had to disconnect and reconnect the iPad to resume charging. This isn't a huge deal, but it does mean you can't just leave the iPad for a few hours and assume it will be charged when you return. The solution is to put a battery pack between the charger and the iPad if you need plug-and-forget functionality.Given the relatively low price of this charger, and its ability to charge smartphones and tablets, it's a great device to have on hand if you live in an area with extended power outages. For me, it's been a good investment.

    Rating: 5

    2013-10-06: In summary this is a pretty decent and a pleasant surprise in a solar charger for electronic devices. It charges my Galaxy Note 2 (3,100 mAh battery) in 3 hours no matter where I am as long as the sun is out. Price is a bit high at $50, but it performs better than others.To test it out, I put the charger in direct sunlight, angled directly at the sun, and turned it periodically to keep it aligned. The Note 2 was idle with the screen off running Battery Monitor Widget from the app store. The rate was approx 30%/hour, meaning I was getting about 1.5 amps of charge. Factoring in the limited juice it was pulling while operating, that's decently close to 2 amps.There's no way you'll be able to have this device pay for itself in any close-to-reasonable amount of time though.My 2A 5V charger takes 2 hours to charge the battery. Assuming 1 full charge per day, that's 20W of energy consumed, and at electrical rates of $0.12/kWh that's $0.0024/day. Yes, it takes 1/4th of a penny to charge your phone. 57 years later, it'll pay for itself at $50/device. Of course if you live/work someplace with no/limited power, have sun every day, and are outdoors all the time, then this would work for you. Otherwise, it's just a handy every-now-and-then thing to have while camping or enjoying the outdoors.(Thanks to "Dan" for a correction on my numbers)Pros:- Has a pocket for various accessories.- Thick, rough burlap feel to the material - seems durable.- Two USB ports - though of course you'll be halving the charge between the two devices.Cons:- Pocket shouldn't be used to store the phone while charging. The whole case gets very hot. Perhaps this should have come with a mini umbrella or something to shade the phone.- It would have been nice to have something built into the case to support it at just the right angle. Instead I had to make do with a piece of wood or a few rocks to keep it up.- A bit heavy and large for light-weight backpacking, but it'll do just fine for campsites, boats, etc...

    Rating: 5

    2013-11-22: This panel is small and light weight yet will put out some decent power to charge phones or tablets. Testing this during the summer months on a bright sunny day the iPhone will charge, but as soon as the output drops (clouds pass in front of the sun etc) the phone will stop charging. I paired this with aNew Trent iCarrier 12000mAh Portable Dual USB Port External Battery Charger/Power Pack for Smartphones, Tablets and more (Now w/Micro-USB charge port)as a source that charges during the day and then I use the battery pack to charge the electronics at night.The small size means it can go with you while camping or going any place. Folded up, this is about 8"x6"x1". The weight is about a pound. Unfolded you have three panels that send power to a small USB outlet located in a pouch on the backside of the panel. The pouch has room to store cords or a small USB battery charger.This is a great item to have for the price point. When used with a battery pack there is no problem keeping the phones and devices charged every night when we are at the camp, (which is off the grid).I would highly recommend this item to anyone needed a clean silent way to charge devices.

    Rating: 5

    2012-11-23: I got this panel to use during power outages to keep the gadgets charged. It works. When the sun is out in force, it works pretty well. I've tested several cellphones (including 2 at a time) as well as a Kindle Fire HD, and it does in fact charge them all. If I could leave it at that then this would be a 5 star item.But it has a significant flaw. As others have mentioned, if there is any interruption in the solar input - a cloud passing in front of the sun, creeping shadows fron trees or fences later in the day - then the unit stops charging altogether. I found this to be very frustrating, as I have had to keep checking and moving the unit and charging devices far more frequently than I'd like. I don't want a panel that I have to babysit. You often don't know if it's stopped; everything can look perfectly fine, then you go and check it and it's where it was an hour ago because some random cloud cast a shade on the panel and shut the device's charging cycle off...If you have nice, bright sun all day long and a large open area where shadows will not be a problem, then this charger will work great, because it IS a capable charger in those conditions. If you don't have that then it can be frustrating. Does it still work? Yes, but you have to constantly check on it, resetting your devices (unplugging them and then plugging them back in) very frequently. Without this flaw I'd give it 5 stars, as it is I'd give it maybe 3.5. So it works, just not as great as I'd hoped.I would only recommend buying this one if you have a large open area that won't be affected by shadows. If you have that then by all means get this one, if not, there are other options.

    Rating: 3

    2012-06-22: This seemed to be the best bang for the buck when it comes to solar chargers. 10W @ 5V =2 Amps of power max. So in direct light this thing should have no issue charging any USB device as the standard is 5V 1 Amp so it will have some power left over.Most USB battery backups that charge off of usb only take 1amp also so charging one of these should be no issue. I have a 4000mAh backup that it charges just fine. I am thinking of getting a 8000mAh USB chargeable and putting that inside the pouch always hooked up to the panel. That is one other nice feature, The USB ports are in a large pouch on the panel that has enough room for a backup battery pack and a cell phone to fit into.Now for low light charging is is best to not expect much in terms of charging a large capacity battery. However outside on the in the shade it was able to charge my Droid 3. And that is a power hungry phone.All the "solar chargers" with tiny panels on them are worthless, Do not even bother wasting money on them and get this instead.

    2013-11-19: I have not used this daily, but have taken it on two camping trips so far. It has charged my cell phone and my Samsung 7 inch tablet. I tried doing both at once and was not thrilled with the speeds but one-on-one they did great. Charged in approximately the same amount of time that it would off a wall wart. Several times I have used this to charge my phone with the light coming through double paned glass and it has done just fine.

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-03: Upon first inspection, this panel is smaller than I expected it to be (makes it easier to pack), it has several well-placed loops to attach it to a variety of items, and it seems to be made of that durable ballistic nylon that many of these panels are made of. I wouldn't say it's all-weather, but it looks like there was at least some thought put into its construction.My test conditions: Full sun (no clouds), within 1-2 hours of "solar noon" as determined by timeanddate.com for my location, and a little over a week after the summer solstice. This translates to about the best conditions I could expect in the field. I also tested after a few clouds rolled in and later again when it had clouded up considerably (perhaps 4-5 hours after "solar noon"). Note: my test location was at the IL/WI state line, so locations further south (toward the equator) might get better results while locations any further from the equator may be worse. To perform this test, I sacrificed an old USB cable, cut off the proprietary connector (for a device I no longer have) and stripped the red and black wires inside the cable and connected them to alligator clips. (This USB cable was not a data cable, so it did not have the four wires; only the two). Plugged the USB end into the panel and I then connected those red and black alligator clips to the red and black probes on my digital multimeter. Follow me so far? Is it the absolute best way to test output? Probably not. There some power loss possible in the several separate connections before it gets to the multimeter. But this was the cheapest method of testing the panel's output. (I was only using one of the two available USB ports on the panel at a time. I tested both, and they were about equal in results).Test results:1.779A x 5.21V = 9.27W (Full sun)1.57A x 5.24V = 8.23W (90% Sunny, wispy cumulous clouds)0.27A x 5.28V = 1.43W (70-80% Cloudy or Overcast)As you can see, it's not quite 10 watts. Part of the issue could be that this panel has a pretty good voltage regulator built in, so you're not sending more than a nominal increase over 5 volts into your device. I have another panel that over-performed its specs, but it also did not regulate the voltage as well as this one, as it fluctuated occasionally over 5.5 volts. This panel is rated for 2 amps at 5 volts. I would love to see the meter get into the 2's in the amperage, so I'll keep testing and probably update this review if I see a test result that puts this panel at or above 10 watts. I deducted one star for not meeting the advertised specs for now, but will update that as well if it does meet or exceed it in the future.For the size of this panel, it's pretty impressive and a good solar panel is a must-have if you want to keep your gizmos powered up while you're away from conventional power sources.

    Rating: 4

    2012-06-23: The Instapark Solar Charger came to me all folded up in a box. My very first impression is that it looked like a case for a Kindle Fire. Open it up and it has three panels. On the back is a pocket which stores two USB ports with enough room to keep a phone or other small device while charging.The first thing I tried to charge was my Kindle 3G . . . inside the car in the front seat on a sunny day. I know instructions say direct sunlight, but I didn't want something screaming "electronic device" staring out the front window of my car. That didn't work.Next, I tried putting it in the window of my home office. This is a south facing window which gets very bright, though not direct, sunlight. On this morning, it happened to be overcast. I tried charging my children's spy watch. No go.The sun came out and I decided I needed to go all out and put it in direct sunlight with the spy watch. Voila! A very quick charge. It works!Now, since it was so bright outside, I tried charging both my Kindle 3G and myIncredicharge I-5000 External Battery Packthrough the front office window at the same time. The Incredicharge charged extremely slowly. The Kindle 3G still would not charge.Again, I brought the Instapark outside to charge the Incredicharge Battery in direct sunlight. Whoa! Another quick charge.One more time. This time, I attempt to charge my Kindle 3G in direct sunlight. It was outside all day. I'd come out to check it every now and then. Yes, it did charge, a little, very slowly. After a full day, my Kindle 3G went from critically low battery levels to half charged.So, this Instapark Solar Charger does work very well for some devices. It really does need direct sunlight. It doesn't work so well in shaded or cloudy conditions. I think I need something with a little more oomph to charge my Kindle 3G. I like the portability, the pocket for storing small devices while charging, the "green" aspect, and the aesthetically appealing case. It's a good idea for camping, but I would recommend trying it out before leaving.This product was provided for review by Instapark.

    Rating: 4

    2012-12-25: So far this device has produced enough juice to charge my Bluetooth, and nothing else. That's after sitting in direct sunlight for half an hour. I'll try it again sometime but so far its a low rating from me.

    Rating: 3

    2012-07-29: In bright sunlight this thing is awesome, provides almost the full 2A of charging power. But in times where clouds can temporarily block the sun or a person or object can cast a shadow it will interrupt the charger and not always continue charging.Do yourself a huge favor and use this with a quality usb battery charger. Charge the battery pack with the solar charger and then charge whatever device you want with the battery pack and avoid leaving your device out in the hot sun.Now the one big problem I have with this solar charger is its durability. The solar panels will break/crack easy if you're not careful how you pack it and the panels have no protective cover or coating and scratch extremely easy which over time could possibly affect how well the panels can collect light. Just from opening and closing the panels they collected several swirl scratches.But for the price when compared to other similar solar chargers, this can't be beat.

    Rating: 4

    2012-07-12: I love the idea of using solar energy panels to power my iPhone, iTouch, Kindle and Kindle Fire. These newer devices go through battery power at a much faster rate than our old devices. So this Instapark 10 Watt Solar Panel Portable Solar Charger is a nice way to save on electricity costs and know that you're doing something good for the environment.This is a high quality solar charger with three panels measuring 19 x 9 inches. It's size is very handy since it folds into something that looks like a tablet cover measuring 6.6 x 9 inches when closed. It's made of a durable looking black material that has a velcro closure on one side and a pocket on the back which contains two USB ports and has enough room to keep a phone or other small device while charging. It's lightweight and would fit easily in a backpack or briefcase or even in a good sized purse. It's easy to take along.Since it was pretty hot here when I tested this, I used connector cords that came with the iPods and iPhones and tablets which were about 3 feet long so that I could keep the devices out of the sun. I used a patio table with an umbrella and just moved the panel and devices as the sun moved. It took less than 2 hours to charge an iPhone in full sun. The amount of time it takes to charge something depends on the time of day and whether it's cloudy or clear. Occasionally on a day when there were quite a few clouds my Kindle would stop charging and I'd have to unplug and plug it in again to get the charging re-started. But in full sun there were no interruptions.I've also tried using this in the house, in front of a window with the sun streaming in and in my car with the panel sitting on the dash (not moving) and it charged, but more slowly. Because it folds, it's easy to prop the panel up in different directions to catch the sun later in the day. This would be very handy when camping or hiking or when away from home and needing to charge any of these devices. And I feel good about using energy from the sun and saving money in the process. After all of your devices are charged, and it's still sunny, you can store some of that energy by charging and external battery like theIncredicharge I-5000 External Battery Pack and Charger 5000mAh Capacity for Apple Iphone 4 4s iPod Touch (1G 2G 3G 4G 5G), Motorola Droid Razr MAXX, HTC Android EVO, Blackberry, Samsung EPIC, Samsung Galaxy Tablet, Samsung Galaxy S and Many More Devicesor theAnker Astro3 10000mAh Dual 2A USB Output External Battery Backup and Charger for iPhone 4S / 4 / 3GS, iPod, iPad, iPad 2, the New iPad (iPad 3); Most Android Phones (Samsung Galaxy S / S2 / S3, HTC One X One S Sensation EVO, Motorola Droid, LG Optimus,...]. These charge more slowly but it's a great way to be able to use some of that energy on a rainy day.I was provided a free sample of the device for testing and to provide an impartial review.

    Rating: 5

    2012-06-25: I bought this to use while hiking and backpacking to keep things like camera, GoPro and GPS charged. Just spent 6 days in the Grand Canyon and found that I wasted a lot of sunlight because everything charged so fast!For the most part, I kept this strapped to my pack hanging from top to bottom so that it would get sun while I hiked. I then had it plugged into a 5000mAh battery pack that I would charge during the day, and would use the battery pack to charge devices once I was in camp. Next day, recharge the battery pack. There were several days we were at camp by 9 or 10am, so on those days I would set the charger in the sun and plug the battery pack AND a device like my GoPro or fellow hiker's iPods in to charge. Charges rarely took more than 2 hours and usually were done in about an hour for partially charged devices. The last 2 days of the hike I didn't even bother strapping it to my pack...it charged things so fast in camp that it was redundant.All in all, I'm very happy with this unit and I felt like I was wasting sunlight when not charging something. The two USB ports combined with the fold up design make this a major win!

    Rating: 5

    2013-12-10: Bought this for my go to hell bag, it had to produce enough power to charge a ipad. it doesn't come with a battery, but even with out a battery it charged my ipad to about 70%, for somthing this small that is great. It will charge my battery paks and they will charge my Ipad and other eletronics..It is small enought to hang on my pack so I can hike while charging

    Rating: 5

    2013-07-25: It actually charged our Lenovo Thinkpad Tablet (the Android one) in a day. Yes, it was a full bright day, but this gadget won't charge plugged into the wall without its dock in less than 8 hours. I think it took about 3 hours to charge our SG3 and 4 or so to charge the Galaxy Note (it was a long camping trip).I have one reservation, though, the glass, or whatever it is, scratches very easily. Diffuse light doesn't work as well (for much of anything but pretty pictures). I may be back to change my review after some use.     Rating: 5

    2013-10-30: I've been using this off & on now for about two months, and regret waiting so long before purchasing it. I honestly wish I'd taken the money I spent on little key chain & other spare batteries, and instead invested in things of this nature. Far less dead weight, far less detrimental to the earth, and far more reliable.Whether I'm up on a mountainside, or down in the city dealing with highrises, I'm almost always able to get a good charge from this. Depending on the sunlight & aim of the panels, I've managed to charge a Droid smartphone in about 2 hours, a Jensen SMPS600 speaker in about the same. Charging larger items like the Kindle Fire HD (7 inch) takes far longer, but it's still perfectly possible to charge, as well as another one or two smaller devices on the same day.The only thing I would change about this, and will look for in my next purchase of this sort, is for something more water-friendly. I've gotten this one damp, and had no problems. But I wouldn't want to submerge this, or ever leave it strapped on the outside of my pack if there's even a nominal chance of precipitation.

    Rating: 5

    2014-02-11: My dad is a missionary and was planning on making a trip to spend two months out in the jungles of Papua New Guinea with some tribes. He planned to show films in their native language using a Optoma PK102 PICO Pocket Projector and a HMDX battery powered speaker. There is no electricity where he was going so he needed a way to recharge his equipment that was portable because they had to get to the villages over land on foot through the mountains.After much searching, I settled on this unit. I am happy to say that this device worked better then expected. He was able to show more then 2 hours of video each night for the two months he was back in the jungle off of just the power he got from this unit during the day. I set him up with New Trent 12000mAh external power pack, which he used this solar panel to charge during the day. He then used the power pack to charge and run his equipment at night. He said that on a good sunny day, this panel could fully charge the 12000mAh power pack in about 6 hours. Honestly, I thought he might be able to show a movie every couple of days, but that was not the case. This unit out performed my expectations.

    Rating: 5

    2011-03-12: The battery I recieved had 0 volts and would not take a charge.The price was excellent but these are old shelved battery bargains sometimes, and once a lithium battery gets below a certain voltage it chemically changes progressively from much less capacity all the way down to no capacity like mine was.I gave the battery a 3 because I'm sure that like the one already in my phone it does a fine job, when it still is chemically viable.I just wanted to warn that it's better to pay a few bucks more and get one that has been made within the last 3 years or so. I think mine was probably the better part of 5-7 years to have achieved 0 voltage and 0 performance.I don't mind Companies buying lots of older batteries and selling them at bargain prices, but they should test them to make sure they have not degraded.Yes, I know I am reviewing the battery not the Company, but I must say even the battery in my phone seems hungry all the time although it may just be my phones nanny software being over-protective.

    2013-05-10: This is the pinnacle of capitalism.I'm not exaggerating. Imagine telling someone from just 50 years ago that you could have a device with which you could access all the world's knowledge or play games, could help you communicate to nearly anyone in the solar system and take pictures of them with a decent camera that you could share with everyone else in the solar system, could entertain with music, movies, or audiobooks, can track your exact location and speed using GPS while you're beating Kenyans in a street race, and most importantly of all, let you get see the latest from your favorite Internet celebrity cat. Then imagine that you tell him it only takes a couple hours of work to make the money to pay for it.This phone is the phenomenal. Of course, it's not the best phone out there--the iPhone or the Galaxy SIII take the cake on that, but unlike its predecessor (ATT Fusion 1), it actually works and it works pretty well at that. The storage and memory seem to allow you to do everything that you want to do. You can't store a billion songs on it, but you can store several audiobooks. And the keyboard is infantile compared to the Apple keyboard, but it's not a deal breaker for what I need this puppy for.I can maintain my Google Voice/Skype/GoPhone system and save hundreds of dollars on my phone bill every year (read my books for more on this dandy) and still accomplish everything I want. It's utter brilliance. Kudos and I look forward to the next generation!

It's not going to do the things a high end smartphone can do and it's not going to perform like a high end smartphone because it's not. I am an HTC One X user and I can honestly say that I am very impressed with this phone. Great starter smartphone for anyone and I highly recommend it - so far!

    A great description that explains what this product is all about. Here's what you get!

    2009-10-16: Raves:When used as a headset for Skype, the microphone is surprisingly effective. Sound quality is much better than with tiny in-the-ear devices.Comfort and battery life is also excellent -- I charge mine overnight and wear it all day long.Cautions:Extending and retracting the adjustable headband should be done with care.     2009-09-08: I got my headset the other day. To my surprize they are rather large, but hey they fit better than my Sony BT22 headset. I guess as long as your listen to your music they don't look so crazy wearing them outside.Now sound quality is not bad.
